Every person desiring to secure the protection intended to be provided by the regulations pertaining to soliciting contained in this Article, shall
comply with the following directions:
Notice of the determination by the occupant of giving invitation to solicitors, or the refusal of invitation to solicitors, to any residence, shall be given
in the manner as follows:
A weatherproof card, approximately three inches by four inches (3" x 4") in size, shall be exhibited upon or near the main entrance door to the
residence, indicating the determination by the occupant, containing the applicable words as follows:
ONLY SOLICITORS REGISTERED IN BROADVIEW INVITED
or
NO SOLICITORS INVITED
The letters shall be at least one-third inch (1/3") in height. For the purpose of uniformity the cards shall be provided by the Village to persons
requesting at no charge. Such card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor of the determination by the occupant of the
residence of the information contained thereon. (1987 Code)
3-6B-6: DUTY OF SOLICITORS:
It shall be the duty of every solicitor upon going onto any premises in the Municipality upon which a "residence" as herein defined is located to
first examine the notice provided for in Section 3-6B-5 of this Article, if any is attached, and be governed by the statement contained on the
notice. If the notice states "ONLY SOLICITORS REGISTERED IN BROADVIEW INVITED", then the solicitor not possessing a valid certificate
registration as herein provided, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises; and if the notice states "NO SOLICITORS INVITED",
then the solicitor, whether registered or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 73/387
Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when
requested to do so by the occupant. (1987 Code)
3-6B-7: UNINVITED SOLICITING PROHIBITED:
It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near
any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of
securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in "soliciting" as herein defined, in defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence in
accordance with the provisions of Section 3-6B-5 of this Article. (1987 Code)
3-6B-8: TIME LIMIT ON SOLICITING:
It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person whether registered under this Article or not, to go upon any
premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door of a residence located thereon, or rap or knock upon any door, or create any sound in any
other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant
thereof, and engage in "soliciting" as herein defined, prior to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. or after eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. of any weekday, or at any
time on a Sunday or on a State or national holiday. (1987 Code)
3-6B-9: SOLICITING BUSINESS ON STREETS, HIGHWAYS OR PUBLIC SIDEWALKS:
No person shall stand on any street, highway or other thoroughfare or public sidewalk in the Village for the purpose of soliciting business,
employment or sales from the driver or occupant of any motor vehicle. (1987 Code)
Footnote 1: See Article C of this Chapter.
ARTICLE C. CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS
3-6C-1: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
A. Solicitors: In accordance with State law, no person shall stand on a highway or street within the Village for the purpose of soliciting
contributions from the occupant of any vehicle except as specifically permitted herein.
B. Soliciting Agencies: Solicitation on highways and streets within the Village shall be permitted for only those soliciting agents which meet the
requirements contained herein. (1987 Code)
3-6C-2: REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
Soliciting agencies shall be registered with the Attorney General as a charitable organization as provided in "An Act to regulate a solicitation and
collection of funds for charitable purposes, providing for violations thereof, and making an appropriation thereof", approved July 26, 1963, as
amended1, and such agencies must be engaged in a Statewide fundraising activity. (1987 Code)
3-6C-3: APPLICATION TO SOLICIT, LIABILITY INSURANCE:
Soliciting agencies shall make application upon a form provided by the office of the Village Clerk wherein it shall be liable for, and indemnify the
Village, against any injuries to any person or property during the solicitation which is related to an act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting
agent. Such agencies shall present proof of public liability insurance in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for personal injury and
five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for property damage, and show the Village as an additional insured. (1987 Code)
3-6C-4: APPROVAL OF SOLICITATION REQUEST:
All requests for permission to solicit hereunder shall be approved by the President and Board of Trustees before solicitation commences. (1987
Code)
3-6C-5: CONDITIONS OF SOLICITATIONS:
A. Location: Solicitation on streets and highways within the Village shall be allowed only at intersections where all traffic is required to come to a
full stop.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 74/387
B. Minors: Soliciting agencies shall not permit solicitation by any person under seventeen (17) years of age.
C. Clothing: Soliciting agencies shall cause any person engaged in the act of solicitation to be wearing a high-visibility vest. (1987 Code)
3-6C-6: VIOLATION:
Any person who violates the provisions of this Article shall be in violation of State law2 and shall be subject to prosecution thereunder. (1987
Code)
Footnote 1: 225 ILCS 460/1 et seq.
Footnote 2: 625 ILCS 5/11-1006.
Chapter 7
SECONDHAND DEALERS AND PAWNBROKERS
3-7-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate or conduct a secondhand store in the Village without having first obtained a license therefor or without complying with the
provisions of this Chapter. (1987 Code)
3-7-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE, INVESTIGATION:
Application for such license shall be made to the Village Clerk in writing and shall state the location intended to be occupied. Upon receipt of any
such application, the Chief of Police or any person authorized by him or by the President to do so, shall investigate the character of the applicant.
No license shall be issued to any person of bad character nor to any person who shall have been convicted of receiving stolen goods, burglary or
robbery. (1987 Code)
3-7-3: RECORDS REQUIRED, INSPECTION:
Every person operating a secondhand store shall keep a record of all articles purchased, which record together with the articles themselves shall
be open to inspection by any member of the Police Department at all reasonable hours. (1987 Code)
3-7-4: PAWNBROKER'S LICENSE REQUIRED1:
No person operating a secondhand store shall do business as a pawnbroker without having obtained a pawnbroker's license in addition to the
secondhand dealer's license. (1987 Code)
Chapter 8
TAXICABS
3-8-1: DEFINITION OF TAXICAB:
For the purpose of this Chapter, the term "taxicab" shall mean and include all vehicles, however propelled, which carry passengers for hire upon
or along the streets of the Village, except vehicles operating regularly upon established routes. (1987 Code)
3-8-2: LICENSES REQUIRED1:
A. Business License: No person shall operate or maintain any taxicab without first obtaining a license therefor and unless the license is in full
force.
B. Driver's License: No person shall operate a taxicab as the driver thereof without first having obtained a driver's license in the manner set forth
in this Chapter, and unless the license is in full force. (1987 Code)
3-8-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 75/387
A. Business License: Any person desiring a license for any taxicab shall file an application therefor with the Village Clerk setting forth the name,
business and address of the applicant, a full description of the motor vehicle for which a license is desired, including the make, model, motor
and engine number and the State license number, and any other information that the President or the Village Clerk may require.
B. Driver's License: Any person desiring a license as a driver of a taxicab shall file an application with the Village Clerk setting forth the name,
sex, residence address, date and place of birth, former occupation, experience as a driver and such other information as the President or
Village Clerk may require. (1987 Code)
3-8-4: ISSUANCE OF LICENSES:
A. Business License: The license for a taxicab shall be issued upon conformance with the terms of this Chapter.
B. Driver's License: The license required by subsection 3-8-2B of this Chapter shall be issued by the Village Clerk to all persons of good moral
character who have complied with this Chapter and with all the laws of the State governing taxicab drivers. No license shall be issued to any
person under the age of twenty one (21) years. (1987 Code)
3-8-5: LICENSE FEES:
Fees for licenses required herein shall be as provided in Section 3-1A-1 of this Title. Said license fees shall be paid semiannually, in advance.
(1987 Code)
3-8-6: INFORMATION REQUIRED TO BE CARRIED:
A. Certificate For Taxicab: All licenses under this Chapter must be accompanied by a satisfactorily completed "vehicle inspection report" as
designated in Section 3-8-10 of this Chapter in order for the Village Clerk to issue a certificate for each taxicab so licensed and so inspected.
This certificate shall at all times be firmly affixed above the Village sticker.
B. Driver's License To Be Carried At All Times: Every driver shall carry the license issued to him under this Chapter at all times that he is driving
or on duty with any such taxicab, and shall exhibit it upon demand to any Village police officer or law enforcement officer.
C. Rates Posted: The rates as approved by the President and Board of Trustees shall be posted in plain view in every licensed taxicab.
D. Additional Information Required: In addition to having the approved rates posted, the name of the driver, his or her picture and the State
license number shall be posted in each taxicab in front of the passenger compartment in such a position that it will be in plain view of
passenger(s) riding therein and so lighted as to be plainly visible at night. (1987 Code)
3-8-7: REVOCATION OF LICENSES:
A. Business License: The President shall have the right to revoke any taxicab license issued under this Chapter whenever the taxicab is not kept
in the mechanical or sanitary condition required by this Chapter, or is not equipped with a governor or other similar device in good repair. Any
such revocation shall be in compliance with the procedure set out in Section 3-1-11 of this Title.
B. Driver's License: The President shall have the right to revoke any license issued under this Chapter to any person as a taxicab driver
whenever such person violates any of the provisions of this Chapter or any other ordinance governing taxicabs or traffic2, and also whenever it
appears that a person holding any such license is not of a good moral character. (1987 Code)
3-8-8: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
Every owner of a taxicab operating upon streets in the Village shall submit for approval to the President and Board of Trustees, insurance policies
covering liability, property damage and medical coverage in the following amounts:
Bodily injury liability
1 person $200,000.00
2 or more persons 500,000.00
Property damage liability 50,000.00
Medical payments, per person 5,000.00
A cab owner must also have a certificate (filed with the State) for "uninsured motorist" of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) per person and twenty
thousand dollars ($20,000.00) for each accident.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 76/387
Failure to carry such insurance coverage shall subject owner and operator of each taxicab to a minimum fine of twenty five dollars ($25.00) and
not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or revocation of license or both. (1987 Code)
3-8-9: RATES:
A. Approval Of Rates Required: Rates which are to be charged per trip and per person must be first submitted and approved by the President and
Board of Trustees before a license is issued. It shall be unlawful to charge more than the approved rates.
B. Rates On File: The approved rates shall be on file with the Village Clerk. (1987 Code)
3-8-10: VEHICLE EQUIPMENT, CONDITION:
A. Meter Required: Every licensed taxicab shall be equipped with a meter.
B. Mechanical Condition, Safety Test Required: Every taxicab operated upon the streets of the Village shall be kept and maintained in a good and
safe mechanical condition. Every taxicab, during the month of January and the month of July of each year, shall be subject to a safety test by
a duly authorized State testing station. A sticker showing the passing of such safety test must be prominently displayed on the window of
taxicab. The passing of a safety test shall not be a bar at any time to prosecution for operating or causing to be operated a taxicab not in good
and safe mechanical condition. Charges for all safety inspections are to be paid for by the owner of the cab or cab company.
In the event that a safety test by a duly authorized State testing station is not available for taxicabs, the President and Board of Trustees shall
authorize the License Committee to set up a "vehicle inspection report" form, similar to that which the State is presently requiring of trucks.
Said "vehicle inspection report" tests are to be made by a licensed mechanic within the State. This form shall be issued by the Village Clerk to
the applicant requesting a business license. Applicant must return same to the Village Clerk, with all requirements checked off as satisfactory
before a business license certificate can be issued.
C. Sanitary Conditions: Each taxicab shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition at all times. (1987 Code)
3-8-11: OPERATION OF VEHICLE:
A. Manner Of Operation: No taxicab shall be driven, operated or controlled so as to violate any of the parking or traffic regulations of the Village or
so as to obstruct traffic or interfere with the free movement of traffic upon any street, alley or public place.
B. Passengers In Front Seat Prohibited, Exception: No person shall be allowed to ride in the front seat of any taxicab with the driver except at
such times as the rear seat or seats are fully occupied by paying passengers and the person riding in the front seat is a bona fide paying
passenger.
C. Use Of Taxicab Stands Required3: No unemployed taxicab shall stand or be parked upon any public street or alley except at such places as
from time to time shall be designated by the Board of Trustees as taxicab stands and allotted to the particular licensee in question.
D. Operating Under The Influence Of Alcohol Or Controlled Substances: No person shall drive, operate or control any taxicab while under the
influence of intoxicating liquor or controlled substances. (1987 Code)
3-8-12: SOLICITING TRADE PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for the owner or driver of any vehicle licensed as a taxicab, to solicit by word or gesture or otherwise, the patronage of any
person upon any public street in the Village. (1987 Code)
Footnote 1: See Title 7, Chapter 2 of this Code.
Footnote 2: See Title 7 of this Code.
Footnote 3: See subsection 7-4-2F of this Code.
Chapter 9
GASOLINE STATIONS, PUBLIC GARAGES
ARTICLE A. GASOLINE STATIONS
3-9A-1: DEFINITION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 77/387
"Filling stations" or "gasoline stations", as used in this Article, shall mean any building, structure or premises, enclosure or other place within the
Village where a container or containers, tank or tanks, either portable or stationary and containing ether, carbon bisulphite, gasoline, acetone,
kerosene, hydrocarbon, liquefied petroleum, naphtha, turpentine or other inflammable liquids are kept or located for the purpose of selling,
offering for sale or distributing any such liquid from such container or containers, tank or tanks. (1987 Code)
3-9A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate the business of a filling station without first having obtained a license therefor. (1987 Code)
3-9A-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE1:
The application for such license for a filling station shall conform to the general provisions of Chapter 1 of this Title relating to licenses and shall
specify the location of the building, structure, premises, enclosure or other place in which it is proposed to keep such filling station, and the
capacity or capacities in gallons of the containers, tank or tanks. (1987 Code)
3-9A-4: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
Each filling station shall be erected, conducted and maintained in accordance with the provisions of this Code and the ordinances of the Village,
the State statutes and the rules of the State Fire Marshal. Each filling station shall be inspected at least twice every year by the Bureau of Fire
Prevention2 or some person duly authorized to make such inspection. It shall be the duty of the person making such inspection to see that the
premises are maintained in compliance to this and other sections of this Code to see that there is no dangerous accumulation of waste or other
combustible material on the premises, and to report to the President any violation which may be discovered during such inspection. (1987 Code)
3-9A-5: LOCATION:
A. Restricted: No filling station or gasoline station or any installation for the storing and handling of inflammable liquids shall hereafter be
constructed or maintained in the Village within two hundred feet (200') of any dwelling, school, hospital, church, theater or any public meeting
place. The two hundred feet (200') shall be measured from the extremities of the tracts of property in question.
B. Frontage Consents Required In Residential Districts: It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any such filling station anywhere in the Village
where a majority of the buildings lying wholly within a radius of three hundred feet (300') are used for residential purposes without having first
secured the written consent of the owners of two-thirds (2/3) of the lots or parcels of land lying within such radius. (1987 Code)
3-9A-6: SELF-SERVICE GAS STATIONS:
Self-service gas stations are permissible for operation in the Village. (1987 Code)
3-9A-6-1: RULES AND REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
Rules and regulations relating to the storage, transportation, sale and use of gasoline and volatile oils, and the law prescribing the color and label
for gasoline or benzol receptacles, are hereby adopted by reference3. (1987 Code)
3-9A-6-2: PERMIT TO OPERATE:
A. Permit Required: It is hereby unlawful for any individual to operate a self-service gas station in the corporate limits of the Village unless said
individual has first obtained a permit for the operation thereof.
B. Information Required: Prior to issuance, an individual must display the following:
1. A permit issued by the State Fire Marshal of the State of Illinois;
2. An accurate description of the location of the self-service gas station;
3. The name, address and phone number of the individual owning and operating the self-service gas station and the name, address and
phone number of the individual owning the property in question.
C. Fee: Said permit shall require a fee as provided in Section 3-1A-1 of this Title.
D. Issuance: All said permits issued for the operation of a self-service gas station shall be issued by the Fire Chief of the Village.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 78/387
E. Permit In Addition To Filling Station License: The permit required by this Section is in addition to and separate from the license required for a
gasoline filling station. (1987 Code)
3-9A-6-3: RESTRICTIONS:
A. Employment Of Minors: No individual shall be permitted to be employed at a self-service gas station unless said individual has attained the age
of sixteen (16) years.
B. Use Of Pumps:
1. Licensed Drivers: Self-service pumps are to be used only by licensed drivers.
2. Minor: No individual shall operate any device used for the pumping of gas within the Village unless that individual has attained the age of
sixteen (16) years.
C. Portable Containers: It is hereby unlawful to sell gasoline by means of a portable container unless said portable container is approved by the
Underwriters Laboratory and is six (6) gallons or less in capacity. (1987 Code)
3-9A-6-4: PENALTY:
Any violation of this Section 3-9A-6 is hereby declared to be an offense and is punishable by a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00)
but not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per occurrence. Each day that a violation continues shall be interpreted as a separate
occurrence. (1987 Code)
ARTICLE B. PUBLIC GARAGES
3-9B-1: DEFINITION:
A "public garage" shall mean the building and grounds used for the storage of vehicles and/or the repair or maintenance of vehicles. (1987 Code)
3-9B-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate or maintain a public garage in the Village without having first obtained a license therefor. (1987 Code)
3-9B-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE1:
Applications for licenses shall be made in writing to the Village Clerk and shall state the location of the garage and the number of cars which can
be accommodated therein. (1987 Code)
3-9B-4: INSPECTIONS:
A. Premises: It shall be the duty of the Fire Chief to make or cause to be made such inspections of public garages in the Village as may be
necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this Article.
B. Vehicles: Any police officer shall be permitted at any reasonable hour to view every car stored in any public garage, and it shall be unlawful to
hinder any such inspection or to conceal any car or motor vehicle from such inspection. (1987 Code)
3-9B-5: BUILDING AND LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
A. Generally: It shall be unlawful to maintain or operate any public garage in any building which does not conform to the requirements of the
building code2.
B. Frame Building: It shall be unlawful to maintain or operate any public garage in a frame building.
C. Location Restricted: It shall be unlawful to maintain or operate any public garage within fifty feet (50') of any building or structure used for
church, school or theater purposes.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 79/387
D. Premises To Be Clean, Safe From Fire: The premises of every garage must be clean and free from inflammable waste material. (1987 Code)
Footnote 1: See Section 3-1A-1 of this Title for license fees.
Footnote 2: See Section 9-1-2 of this Code.
Chapter 10
ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS1
3-10-1: ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR DEFINED:
The term "electrical contractor" as used in this Chapter shall mean any person engaged in the business of installing or altering equipment and
electrical appliances for the utilization of electricity supplied for light, heat or power not including radio apparatus or equipment for wireless
reception of sounds and signals, and not including apparatus, conductor and other equipment installed for or by public utilities, including common
carriers, which are under the jurisdiction of the Illinois Commerce Commission for use in their operation as public utilities. The term "electrical
contractor" does not include employees employed by such contractor to do or supervise such work. (1987 Code)
3-10-2: CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
A. Village Contractors: No person shall engage in the business of electrical contractor without having first obtained a certificate of registration
therefor as herein required.
B. Out Of Town Contractors, Fee Exemption: Any electrical contractor who is registered as such in any other city or village in the State shall not
be required to pay a fee for being registered in this Village, but every person doing business in this Village as an electrical contractor shall
secure a certificate of registration. Such certificate shall be issued without charge to electrical contractors registered as such under the
ordinances of another city or village in this State. (1987 Code)
3-10-3: APPLICATION FOR CERTIFICATE:
Applications for such certificate shall be made to the Village Clerk and a list of all contractors registered shall be given by the Village Clerk to the
Chief Electrical Inspector. (1987 Code)
3-10-4: REGISTRATION FEE:
The annual fee for registering as an electrical contractor shall be as provided in subsection 9-3-1D1a of this Code; provided that an application
made after the expiration of the first six (6) months of the register year shall be issued upon the payment of one-half (1/2) of this fee. The register
year shall correspond with the license year. (1987 Code)
3-10-5: COMPLIANCE WITH ELECTRICAL REGULATIONS, INSTALLATION PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person registered under the provisions of this Chapter to install any electrical appliances, wiring or fixtures without
strict compliance with the regulations relating to such fixtures; and it shall be unlawful for any such person to do any such work without having
obtained such permits as may be required. (1987 Code)
Footnote 1: See Section 9-3-3 of this Code.
Chapter 11
COMMERCIAL LAUNDRIES AND DRY CLEANERS
3-11-1: COMMERCIAL LAUNDRIES:
3-11-1-1: DEFINITION:
A "commercial laundry" is hereby defined as a commercial establishment wherein clothing and household furnishings are laundered. (1987 Code)
3-11-1-2: LICENSE REQUIRED, EXCEPTION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 80/387
No person shall operate or conduct a laundry in the Village without having first obtained a license therefor; provided, that establishments licensed
as dry-cleaning establishments need not obtain a laundry license in addition to the dry-cleaning license. (1987 Code)
3-11-1-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE1:
Applications for such licenses shall be made in writing to the Village Clerk and shall state thereon the location intended to be occupied. (1987
Code)
3-11-1-4: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
A. Premises: Premises used for laundries must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. No refuse of any kind shall be permitted to accumulate
on such premises, and the premises must be kept free from rats, mice and vermin.
B. Employees: It shall be unlawful to employ any person afflicted with a venereal or any contagious disease in a laundry. (1987 Code)
3-11-1-5: INSPECTIONS:
It shall be the duty of the Fire Chief, or some other person designated by said Chief, to inspect or cause to be inspected every establishment
licensed under this Section at least once every six (6) months. Any violations, under the terms of this Section shall be reported to the Village
President. (1987 Code)
3-11-1-6: COIN-OPERATED LAUNDRIES:
A. Attendant Required: During the hours of operation an adult attendant shall be present at all coin-operated laundries.
B. Closing Hours: All automatic coin-operated laundries shall close at eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M., and no automatic coin-operated laundry shall
remain open between eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M.
C. Compliance With Electrical Code Required: No license for the operation of a coin-operated automatic laundry shall be issued unless the
installation of such coin-operated laundry machines complies with the provisions of the electrical code of the Village2. (1987 Code)
3-11-2: COMMERCIAL DRY CLEANERS:
3-11-2-1: DEFINITION:
A "commercial dry cleaner" is a commercial establishment wherein a process of cleaning garments and textiles by use of chemical solvents
instead of water is conducted. (1987 Code)
3-11-2-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate or conduct a dry cleaning establishment within the village without having first obtained a license. The use of
perchloroethylene (also known as PERC) is prohibited. (Ord. 2008-23, 7-21-2008)
3-11-2-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE3:
Applications for licenses shall be filed with the clerk and referred to the fire chief for investigation and recommendation before a license shall be
issued. Applications shall also state if coal, oil, benzine, turpentine or petroleum will be used at the location. (Ord. 2008-23, 7-21-2008)
3-11-2-4: FRONTAGE CONSENTS REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to establish a dry cleaning establishment in any place where a majority of the buildings within a radius of four hundred feet
(400') are used exclusively for residence purposes without having first secured the written consent of the owners of a majority of the lots or
parcels of ground within such radius. (1987 Code)
3-11-2-5: FIRE REGULATIONS4:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 81/387
A. Buildings: No dry cleaning establishment shall be operated in a frame building, nor in any building which does not comply with the provisions of
this code relating to the construction of buildings5.
B. Inflammable Waste: Such establishment shall be kept as free as possible from inflammable wastes.
C. Open Flames: It shall be unlawful to maintain or permit a stove or open flame of any kind on the premises.
D. Smoking: Smoking in or on such premises is prohibited.
E. Storage And Handling Of Inflammable Liquids: The provisions of this code relating to the storage or handling of inflammable liquids must be
fully complied with in every dry cleaning establishment. (1987 Code)
3-11-2-6: COIN OPERATED DRY CLEANERS:
A. Attendant Required: During the hours of operation, an adult attendant shall be present at all coin operated dry cleaners.
B. Closing Hours: All automatic coin operated dry cleaning shops heretofore established and hereafter to be established shall close at eleven
o'clock (11:00) P.M., and no automatic coin operated dry cleaning shop shall remain open between eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. and six o'clock
(6:00) A.M.
C. Compliance With Electrical Code Required: No license for the operation of an automatic coin operated dry cleaning establishment shall be
issued unless the installation of such machines complies with the provisions of the electrical code of the village6. (1987 Code)
3-11-2-7: ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty of the village fire chief to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this section 3-11-2. (1987 Code)
Chapter 12
HOUSE MOVERS
3-12-1: DEFINITION:
A "house mover" is hereby defined to be a business wherein buildings are moved or raised. (1987 Code)
3-12-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of house mover or raiser in the Village without having obtained a license therefor. (1987 Code)
3-12-3: PERMIT TO MOVE BUILDINGS REQUIRED:
Licensed house movers shall file with the Village Clerk application for, and shall secure the necessary permits for moving any building on or over
any public street, sidewalk, alley or other public place. (1987 Code)
3-12-4: BOND:
Each licensed house mover may file an annual bond, conditioned to save the Municipality harmless from any loss, damage or liability resulting
from the conduct of the business by the licensee, in the sum provided in Section 3-1-6 of this Title. If such bond is duly filed, it shall be
unnecessary for such licensee to file a bond for each individual house moved in the Village. (1987 Code)
Chapter 13
MACHINE SHOPS
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 82/387
3-13-1: MACHINE SHOP DEFINED:
The term "machine shop" as used in this Chapter, shall include every workshop in which machines are made or metal parts thereof are repaired,
or where parts of machines or tools, implements, gears, dies, screws or other metal articles are cut, filed, shaped or repaired by means of a lathe
or other machinery. (1987 Code)
3-13-2: LICENSE REQUIRED1:
No person shall operate a machine shop within the Village without having first obtained a license therefor; provided, that this Chapter shall not be
construed as requiring an additional license for any class of machine shops specifically licensed under any other provision of the ordinances of
the Village. (1987 Code)
3-13-3: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
A. Generally: No building, structure or part thereof used for or in connection with any machine shop shall be so used as to endanger the health or
property of the employees or of the public.
B. Premises: The owner, occupant or manager of any machine shop shall cause all floors and other surface around or beneath any machine or
workbench to be kept in good order and repair and shall have suitable, convenient and sanitary receptacles for receiving waste and cloths
used in and about the machine shop for the purpose of cleaning machines or parts thereof or which are intended for any other use.
C. Employees: No person suffering from any actively contagious or infectious disease shall be employed in or about any machine where cutting
compound or fluid is used. All such cutting compound or fluid shall be kept free from infectious or harmful matter. (1987 Code)
3-13-4: HOURS PROHIBITED IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT:
No machine shop shall be operated in the nighttime between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. in any place in
which a majority of the buildings within a radius of four hundred feet (400') are used exclusively for residence purposes. (1987 Code)
3-13-5: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
It shall be the duty of the Fire Chief to make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions
of this Chapter. (1987 Code)
Footnote 1: See Section 3-1A-2 of this Title.
Chapter 14
COIN-OPERATED CAR WASHES1
3-14-1: DEFINITION:
A "coin-operated car wash" is any business where motorized vehicles may be washed upon deposit of coins in payment for use of the business's
facilities. (1987 Code)
3-14-2: LICENSE REQUIRED, FEE:
Any person engaging in the business of coin-operated car wash must first obtain license from the Village Clerk. There shall be a business
registration fee for a coin-operated car wash as provided in Section 3-1A-2 of this Title which shall be paid before engaging in such business.
(1987 Code; amd. Ord. 93-2, 1-19-1993)
3-14-3: DEPOSIT TO WATER DEPARTMENT REQUIRED:
Any person making application for a coin-operated car wash business must deposit fifty dollars ($50.00) for water and such deposit will be
returned at the termination of business. (1987 Code)
3-14-4: BUILDING AND PREMISES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 83/387
A. Building Construction: Each building for a coin-operated car wash must be completely constructed with face brick.
B. Lighting Required: Such building for coin-operated car washes must be illuminated from dusk until dawn, interior and exterior.
C. Driveway Construction: All drives for coin-operated car washes must be installed and constructed with blacktop or concrete. (1987 Code)
3-14-5: ATTENDANT REQUIRED:
There must be an adult attendant present at all times during business hours of a coin-operated car wash. (1987 Code)

Chapter 15
LUMBERYARDS
3-15-1: DEFINITION:
A "lumberyard" is hereby defined as any buildings and/or grounds used for the storage and sale of lumber and allied construction items. (1987
Code)
3-15-2: LICENSE REQUIRED1:
It shall be unlawful to do business as a lumber dealer maintaining a lumberyard, or to operate or maintain a lumberyard in the Village without first
having secured a license therefor. (1987 Code)
3-15-3: FRONTAGE CONSENTS REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to establish any lumberyard anywhere where a majority of the houses within a radius of three hundred feet (300') are used for
residence purposes without having secured the written consent of the owners of two-thirds (2/3) of the lots or parcels of land within such radius.
(1987 Code)
3-15-4: FIRE EQUIPMENT REQUIRED:
Every person owning or operating a lumberyard shall have the same equipped with sufficient firefighting apparatus to handle any small fires which
may start and to prevent their spread. (1987 Code)
3-15-5: PILING LUMBER RESTRICTED:
It shall be unlawful to pile or stack any lumber in such a way that the lumber overhangs or is in danger of falling onto any adjoining property or
street, alley or other public place. (1987 Code)
3-15-6: INSPECTIONS:
It shall be the duty of the Fire Chief to make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to see to the enforcement of the
provisions of this Chapter. (1987 Code)

Chapter 17
CHRISTMAS TREE SALES
3-17-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of selling Christmas trees (evergreen trees) without first having obtained a license therefor. (1987 Code)
3-17-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE1:
Applications for the license shall be made to the Village Clerk, in writing, and shall state the name and address of the applicant, the description of
the place where business is to be conducted and the name and home address of the proprietor, owner or person designated to manage such
place of business. In addition, the applicant shall set forth whether such business is to be conducted on a vacant lot or within a building, structure,
room or enclosure.
Every application for a license shall be approved by the Fire Chief as to the compliance of the premises named therein with the fire regulations of
the Village2 before a license is issued. (1987 Code)
3-17-3: SMOKING PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit smoking in any building, room, structure or enclosure where Christmas trees are being sold. (1987
Code)

Every vehicle used for such business shall have printed thereon in a place easily visible from the side of the vehicle, the name and address of the
