4-6-13: CORRECTION OF VIOLATIONS:
A. The completed inspection report form shall specify a reasonable period of time for the correction of the violations found; and correction of the
violations shall be accomplished within the period specified, in accordance with the following provisions:
1. If an imminent health hazard exists, such as complete lack of refrigeration or sewage backup into the establishment, the establishment shall
immediately cease food operations. Operations shall not be resumed until authorized by the Cook County Department of Public Health.
2. All violations of four (4) or five (5) point weighted items shall be corrected as soon as possible, but in any event, within ten (10) days
following inspection. A follow-up inspection to confirm correction may be conducted at the discretion of the Cook County Department of
Public Health.
3. All one or two (2) point weighted items shall be corrected as soon as possible, but in any event, by the time of the next routine inspection.
4. When the rating score of the establishment is less than sixty (60), the establishment shall initiate corrective action on all identified violations
within forty eight (48) hours. One or more reinspections may be conducted at reasonable time intervals to assure correction.
5. In the case of temporary food establishments, all violations shall be corrected within twenty four (24) hours. If violations are not corrected
within twenty four (24) hours, the establishment shall immediately cease food operations until authorized to resume by the Cook County
Department of Public Health.
B. The inspection report shall state that failure to comply with any time limits for corrections may result in cessation of food operations. An
opportunity for hearing on the inspection findings or the time limitations or both will be provided if a written request is filed with the Village
within ten (10) days following cessation of operations. If a request for hearing is received, a hearing shall be held within twenty (20) days of
receipt of the request.
C. Whenever a food establishment is required under the provisions of this Section to cease operations, it shall not resume operations until it is
shown on reinspection that conditions responsible for the order to cease operations no longer exist. Opportunity for reinspection shall be
offered within a reasonable time. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-14: EXAMINATION AND CONDEMNATION OF FOOD:
Food may be examined or sampled by the Cook County Department of Public Health as often as necessary for enforcement of this Chapter. The
Cook County Department of Public Health may, upon written notice to the owner or person in charge, specifying with particularity the reasons
therefor, place a hold order on any food which it believes is in violation of sections 750.100, 750.110, 760.100, or 760.110 of the Illinois
Department of Public Health's "Food Service Sanitation Code", or the "Retail Food Store Sanitation Code", respectively, or any other section of
this Chapter. The Cook County Department of Public Health shall tag, label, or otherwise identify any food subject to the hold order. No food
subject to a hold order shall be used, served, or moved from the establishment. The Cook County Department of Public Health shall permit
storage of the food under conditions specified in the hold order, unless storage is not possible without risk to the public health, in which case
immediate destruction shall be ordered and accomplished. The hold order shall state that a request for hearing may be filed within ten (10) days
and that if no hearing is requested the food shall be destroyed. If a request for hearing is received, the hearing shall be held within twenty (20)
days after receipt of the request. On the basis of evidence produced at that hearing, the hold order may be vacated, or the owner or person in
charge of the food may be directed by written order to denature or destroy such food or to bring it into compliance with the provisions of this
Chapter. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-15: SUBMISSION OF PLANS:
Whenever a food establishment is constructed or extensively remodeled and whenever an existing structure is converted to use as a food
establishment, properly prepared plans and specifications for such construction, remodeling, or conversion shall be submitted to the Village and
the Cook County Department of Public Health for review and approval before construction, remodeling, or conversion is begun. The plans and
specifications shall indicate the proposed layout, arrangement, mechanical plans, and construction materials of work areas, and the type and
model of proposed fixed equipment and facilities. The Village and the Cook County Department of Public Health shall approve the plans and
specifications if they meet the requirements of this Chapter. No food establishment shall be constructed, extensively remodeled, or converted
except in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the Village and the Cook County Department of Public Health. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-
1997)
4-6-16: PREOPERATIONAL INSPECTION:
Whenever plans and specifications are required by Section 4-6-15 of this Chapter to be submitted to the Village and the Cook County Department
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 103/387
of Public Health, the Village and the Cook County Department of Public Health shall inspect the food establishment prior to the start of operations,
to determine compliance with the approved plans and specifications and with the requirements of this Chapter. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-17: PROCEDURE WHEN INFECTION IS SUSPECTED:
When the Cook County Department of Public Health has reasonable cause to suspect possible disease transmission by an employee of a food
establishment, it may secure a morbidity history of the suspected employee or make any other investigation as indicated and shall take
appropriate action. The Cook County Department of Public Health may require any or all of the following measures:
A. The immediate exclusion of the employee from employment in food establishments;
B. The immediate closing of the food establishment concerned until, in the opinion of the Cook County Department of Public Health, no further
danger of disease outbreak exists;
C. Restriction of the employee's services to some area of the establishment where there would be no danger of transmitted disease;
D. Adequate medical and laboratory examination of the employee and of other employees and of his and their body discharges. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-
1997)
4-6-18: REINSPECTION COSTS:
In the event a reinspection is deemed necessary by the inspector, the cost of any and all subsequent reinspections shall be borne by the holder of
the permit, license, or certificate. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-19: CONDITIONAL PERMIT, LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE:
When structural, plumbing, electrical, ventilation, or similar such defects exist in an established food facility that may require significant
expenditures to correct, but are not considered to be imminent health hazards, a conditional permit, license, or certificate may be granted at the
discretion of the Village. Under no circumstances will a conditional permit, license, or certificate be issued for more than two (2) consecutive
twelve (12) month periods. The purpose of the conditional license or permit is to allow a reasonable period of time for correction of existing
defects. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-20: PENALTIES:
Any person violating the provisions of this Chapter shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and a separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation continues. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-21: INJUNCTIONS:
The Village shall have the right to enjoin any person or establishment in the event violations occur on a continuing basis. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-22: AUTOMATIC FOOD VENDING MACHINES:
A. Application For License: In addition to the requirements of Section 4-6-4 of this Chapter, application for automatic food vending machine
license shall set forth the following:
1. Types of automatic food vending machines intended to be operated;
2. A description of each type;
3. Such further information as may be required by the Village sanitarian in order to inform him fully as to the type of machine and the kind of
food to be dispensed therefrom.
B. Approval Of Machine, Inspection Of Premises: Before any license shall be issued, the type of vending machine intended to be operated shall
be approved by the sanitarian who also shall cause an inspection to be made of the premises of the applicant to determine the character and
fitness of the premises from the standpoint of ensuring protection of the food from improper handling, dust, dirt, flies, vermin or other
contamination.
C. License Emblem: The Village Clerk shall deliver to each person licensed to engage in a business of installing, keeping or maintaining
automatic food vending machines a license emblem. It shall be the duty of each licensee to properly identify each food vending machine which
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 104/387
he installs. Such identification shall contain the name and business address of the licensee and failure to properly affix and maintain such
identification on each food vending machine shall constitute a violation of this section.
D. Prohibited Acts Or Conditions:
1. Location In Toilet Or Washroom: No automatic food vending machine shall be installed or kept for use in any toilet or washroom.
2. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to install, keep or maintain or use or permit the installation, keeping, maintenance or
use upon his premises of any automatic food vending machine owned or operated by any person who has not obtained a license as
provided herein. (1987 Code; amd. Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-23: MOBILE FOOD VENDORS:
A. Definitions: For the purposes of this section:
LICENSEE: Shall mean any mobile food vendor or mobile food preparer that has been licensed by the Village of Broadview to serve food from
mobile food vehicle.
MOBILE FOOD PREPARER OR PREPARER: Means any person who, by traveling from place to place upon the public ways, including
highways, alleys, sidewalks, or other public ways, prepares and serves, sells or distributes perishable food items from a mobile food vehicle.
MOBILE FOOD VEHICLE OR VEHICLE: Means a manufactured, motorized mobile food unit, including but not limited to trucks, cars or other
vehicles, as well as motorcycles and bicycles, in which ready-to-eat food is cooked, wrapped, packaged, processed, or portioned for service,
sale or distribution. This definition does not include any trucks, cars, other vehicles, motorcycles, or bicycles used to deliver food ordered from
a restaurant with a fixed place of business.
MOBILE FOOD VENDOR OR VENDOR: Means any person who, by traveling from place to place upon public ways, including highways,
alleys, sidewalks, or other public ways, serves ready-to-eat food which is cooked, wrapped, packaged, processed, or portioned for service,
sale or distribution, including selling food prepared by a mobile food preparer, and shall include the owner of mobile food vehicle or the
owner's agent.
B. License Required:
1. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate within the Village a mobile food vehicle or operate as a mobile food
preparer or mobile food vendor, as defined in this section, without first having obtained a license for that purpose.
2. License Application: Any person desiring to operate a mobile food vehicle shall make a written application for such license to the Building
Commissioner or his/her designee. The application for such license shall be on forms provided by the Building Commissioner or his/her
designee and shall include the following:
a. Name, signature and address of each applicant and each corporate officer, owner, partner, or proprietor;
b. Name and address of the approved commercial supply source;
c. A description of the preparation methods and food products offered for sale, including the intended menu, display and distribution
containers;
d. The anticipated volume of food to be stored, prepared and sold;
e. Plans and specifications for the mobile food vehicle, including the proposed layout, photographs, mechanical schematics, construction
materials, finish schedules, equipment types, manufacturers, model numbers, locations, dimensions, weight of vehicle per wheel,
performance capacities, power source, installation specifications and information on any custom fabricated equipment;
f. Proof of full, unfettered and continuous access during hours of operation to restrooms with a hand sink for use by employees within two
hundred feet (200') of the mobile food vehicle during times when the vehicle is parked in one location for more than two (2) hours. Proof
of access shall be evidenced by written agreement between the mobile food vendor and the party providing said access;
g. A valid copy of all necessary licenses or permits required by State health or transportation authorities. This includes proof of food handler
certification training or valid Illinois Food Service Sanitation Manager Certification as required in the Food Handling Regulation
Enforcement Act, 410 Illinois Compiled Statutes 625/0.01 et seq. During all times of mobile food vehicle operation in the Village, at least
one certified trained food handler or someone holding a food service sanitation manager certificate issued by the Illinois Department of
Public Health must be present on the vehicle;
h. A signed statement that the mobile food vendor shall defend, hold harmless, and indemnify the Village and its officers and employees,
and shall indemnify the Village, its officers and employees for any claims for damage to property or injury to persons which may be
occasioned by any activity carried on under the terms of the permit. Mobile food vendor shall furnish and maintain such public liability,
food products liability, and property damage insurance as will protect the mobile food vendor, property owners, and the Village from all
claims for damage to property or bodily injury, including death, which may arise from the operations under the license or in connection
therewith. Such insurance shall provide coverage of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence. The policy shall
further provide that it may not be cancelled except upon thirty (30) days' written notice served upon the Village President and on the
Building Commissioner. A license issued pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be invalid at any time the insurance required
herein is not maintained and evidence of continuing coverage is not filed with the Building Commissioner and the Village President; and
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 105/387
i. The proposed location(s) and times of operation for conducting business in accordance with this section. Mobile food vendors shall be
required to provide to the Village a signed statement that the mobile food vendor shall defend, hold harmless, and indemnify the adjacent
property owner(s) for any claims for damage to property or injury to persons which may be occasioned by any activity carried on or under
the permit. No application will be accepted for a permit to operate at a location where a current permit has been issued or a complete
application is pending. If the proposed location is private property, the applicant shall provide to the Village written consent from the
property owner, which shall be duly notarized.
Mobile food vendor shall notify the Building Commissioner or his/her designee within thirty (30) calendar days of any changes to
application information.
It shall be the duty of the Building Commissioner or his/her designee to inspect the vehicle and determine the fitness and suitability of the
vehicle for its intended use. The Building Commissioner may also direct the applicant to have the vehicle inspected by the Cook County
Department of Health, the costs of which shall be paid by the mobile food vendor.
3. License Fees: All mobile food vendors licensed under this section shall pay an annual license fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). The
fee for any such license issued after July 1 in any calendar year shall equal one hundred twenty five dollars ($125.00). One-day license fees
shall also be available for fifty dollars ($50.00) per day. No more than six (6) one-day licenses will be issued to any applicant in a one year
period.
4. Form And Condition Of Permit: In addition to naming the mobile food vendor, the approved operating location site diagram, and other
information deemed appropriate by the Building Commissioner or his/her designee, the mobile food vehicle vending permit shall contain the
following conditions:
a. Each mobile food vehicle vending license shall expire on December 31 of each year.
b. The license shall not be transferrable from person to person or from place to place without the written approval of the Building
Commissioner or his/her designee.
c. The approved operational location may be changed, either temporarily or permanently, by written notice of the Building Commissioner or
his/her designee.
d. The license is valid for one mobile food vehicle only.
e. There shall be issued to each mobile food vendor a suitable decal that shall be permanently and prominently affixed to the vehicle.
5. Refusal To Issue; Suspension; Revocation: Licenses authorized to be issued pursuant to this section may be suspended, revoked or
refused to be issued upon good cause shown. The Village may refuse to issue, revoke, or suspend a license if any applicant or agent
thereof refuses to comply with any requirement of this section or has a debt that is in arrears to the Village.
C. Location Review And Restrictions:
1. The license shall be referred to the Building Commissioner or his/her designee for approval or disapproval. In the course of his or her
review, the Building Commissioner may, but is not required to, consult with the Director of Public Works, the Police Chief, and the Fire Chief
related to the application for a license and the location(s) at which the license may be used. The use of the licensed operating location for
mobile food vending must be compatible with the public interest in use of the public right-of-way. In making such determination, the Building
Commissioner, in consultation with the Director of Public Works, the Police Chief, and the Fire Chief or their designee shall consider the
width of the public way, parking issues and traffic congestion, the weight that can be supported by the paving or street surface at the
proposed location, the proximity and location of existing street furniture, including, but not limited to, utility poles, parking meters, bus
shelters, benches, street trees, news racks, as well as the presence of bus stops, truck loading zones, taxi stands, valet parking zones, fire
hydrants, or other businesses or approved mobile food vehicles to determine whether the requested location would result in pedestrian or
street congestion.
2. The Building Commissioner or his/her designee shall not approve a location where a mobile food vehicle would substantially obstruct
highways, alleys, sidewalks, or other public ways, impair the movement of pedestrians or vehicles, or pose a hazard to public safety. The
Building Commissioner or his/her designee shall not approve any location which is adjacent to a bus stop, taxi stand, or handicap loading
zone, within thirty feet (30') of an intersection, within three feet (3') of a curb, within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant, within twenty feet (20')
of a fire station or police station, or directly in front of a property entryway. Pedestrian walkways of no less than six feet (6') must be
maintained around the mobile food vehicle.
3. It shall be unlawful for a mobile food vehicle vendor to park, stand, or operate in a location which is adjacent to or within one hundred feet
(100') of the address point of a licensed restaurant. This requirement may be waived if the application is submitted with the duly notarized
written consent of the proprietor of the adjacent restaurant. No person or entity shall either pay or accept payment for the written consent
provided herein. If applicable, this requirement shall not apply to a licensed restaurant affiliated with the mobile food vehicle vendor provided
that satisfactory written proof as determined by the Building Commissioner is provided.
4. The Village shall not approve more than one mobile food vehicle per private parking lot, which must remain in compliance with this Code.
5. Mobile food vendor shall not operate a mobile food vehicle within five hundred feet (500') of the address point of any fair, carnival, circus,
festival, special event, or civic event that is licensed or sanctioned by the Village except when mobile food vendor has obtained a one-day
food permit from the Village.
6. On days when school is in session at elementary, middle, and secondary schools (public or private), it shall be unlawful for any mobile food
vendor to operate a mobile food vehicle within five hundred feet (500') of the address point of property of a school. During summer school
sessions, this restriction shall apply only to those individual schools which are in operation.
7. A mobile food vendor shall not operate on private property within the corporate limits of Village without first obtaining written consent to
operate from the affected private property owner to operate.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 106/387
8. The Building Commissioner, the Director of Public Works, the Police Chief, and the Fire Chief, or their designees, shall work cooperatively
to review and determine location restrictions related to the parking and operation of mobile food vehicles and shall consider public safety
and right-of-way safety issues.
9. Mobile food vehicle vendors may be permitted to operate and locate within locations and times approved by the Building Commissioner.
The license must be prominently displayed on the mobile food vehicle at all times. The mobile food vehicle vendors must pay any and all
parking meter fees for the time and usage of any and all Village parking spaces, including paving parking meter fees for the usage of
multiple parking spaces during operation of the vehicle and must obey all parking and traffic regulations.
D. Sanitation And Inspections:
1. All mobile food vehicles shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. It shall be the duty of the Building Commissioner or his/her
designee, which may include the Cook County Health Department, to make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to
ensure all mobile food vehicles are kept in a clean and sanitary condition. The Building Commissioner or his/her designee, which may
include the Cook County Health Department or his/her designee, bearing proper identification, shall be permitted to enter or access any
mobile food vehicle at any reasonable time for the purpose of inspecting to determine whether the mobile food vendor has complied with the
terms of this section. Additionally, the mobile food vendor shall, on request, provide the Building Commissioner or his/her designee, which
may include the Cook County Health Department, with the records of the mobile food vehicle to obtain information pertaining to food and
supplies purchased, received or used. Denial of access to the mobile food vehicle or to said records shall be deemed an interference with
the Building Commissioner or his/her designee, which may include the Cook County Health Department, in the performance of his/her
duties and may result in an immediate suspension of the mobile food vendor's license.
2. All food storage, preparation and distribution of food, and vehicle equipment must meet applicable Illinois Department of Public Health and
the Cook County Department of Health standards and requirements, as well as standards to be determined by the Building Commissioner
or his/her designee.
3. All food, beverages, ice and other materials sold or used in preparation of goods to be sold must be obtained from an approved commercial
supply source. The Building Commissioner shall be responsible for approving commercial supply sources and shall keep a list of approved
commercial supply sources in a conveniently accessible location.
4. All off-site food preparation and food storage must be done either at a Village of Broadview licensed food establishment or if the mobile food
vehicle vendor is outside the jurisdiction of the Village, it must comply with the applicable requirements of this Code as well as all
requirements of the Cook County Department of Health and the State of Illinois. All mobile food vendors or applicants that intend to
dispense foods that are prepared and wrapped in a commissary, must conduct their operations under the supervision of a State and/or local
health authority. All mobile food vehicle vendors and the mobile food preparers must prepare food in compliance with any and all rules and
regulations of the Illinois Department of Health and the Cook County Department of Health and conducts its operations under the
supervision of a State or local health authority. The mobile food vehicle vendor shall, in addition to the application, if requested, provide
reports including inspection reports and laboratory results from the State and local health authority in the jurisdiction where the food source
or commissary is located, indicating compliance with such approval. Food cannot be prepared in a home, apartment, other living space or
garage.
5. All waste liquids, garbage, litter and refuse shall be kept in leak-proof, nonabsorbent containers which shall be kept covered with tight-fitting
lids and properly disposed of either at an affiliated licensed restaurant or alternative location(s) as disclosed and agreed to with the Building
Commissioner or his/her designee. No waste liquids, garbage, litter or refuse shall be dumped or drained into sidewalks, streets, gutters,
drains, trash receptacles, other than the agreed locations with Village staff. A garbage receptacle shall be easily accessible for customer
use. Mobile food vendors shall be responsible for all litter and garbage left by customers.
E. Restrictions On Use:
1. Hours of operation for mobile food vendors shall be limited to the hours between seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M.
The hours of operation for mobile food vehicles located within three hundred feet (300') of a residential building or a mixed use building with
a residential component shall be limited to the hours between seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. No mobile food vehicle
shall be left unattended on highways, alleys, sidewalks, or other public ways, nor remain on highways, alleys, sidewalks, or other public
ways outside of these allowed hours of operation.
2. No mobile food vehicle vendor shall use or maintain any outside sound amplifying equipment, lights, or noisemakers, such as bells, horns
or whistles to attract attention or customers, except that the vehicle may maintain standard issued vehicle equipment without modifications
to said equipment.
3. No mobile food vehicle shall use external signage, bollards, seating, or any other equipment not contained within the vehicle except that a
retractable awning may be used at the exterior food service and food sales area.
4. The mobile food vehicle shall not have a drive-through.
5. Mobile food vendor shall obey all State, local, and Village laws as well as any lawful order of a police officer to move to a different permitted
location to avoid congestion or obstruction of a public way or remove the vehicle entirely from the public way if necessary to avoid such
congestion or obstruction.
6. The mobile food vehicle must prominently display the name, address, and phone number of the owner.
7. The mobile food vehicle shall display its permit/decal prominently on the vehicle's windshield in the lower right hand corner (passenger's
side) of the windshield.
8. Any power required for the mobile food vehicle located on a public way shall be self-contained and shall not use utilities drawn from the
public right-of-way. Mobile food vehicles on private property may use electrical power from an adjacent property only when the property
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 107/387
owner provides written consent. All other power sources must be self-contained. No power cable or equipment shall be extended at grade
across any Village street, alley or sidewalk.
9. All identifying information, logos, advertising, decorations, or other displays on the exterior of a mobile food vehicle shall conform to this
Code related to regulating commercial signage, to the extent applicable. In particular, exterior displays shall be designed to minimize
confusion or distraction that jeopardizes vehicular and pedestrian safety and shall be harmonious with the surroundings and consistent with
the character of the community in which the mobile food vehicle operates.
F. License Adverse Action:
1. An application or approved license may be denied, revoked, suspended, or not renewed for any of the following reasons listed herein,
however, this list is not exhaustive and licenses could be denied, revoked, suspended or not renewed for other reasons provided good
cause is shown. Some of the reasons that licenses may be denied, revoked, suspended, or not renewed, include but are not limited to:
a. The application contains material omissions or false, fraudulent, or deceptive statements.
b. The vehicle is operated in such a manner as constituting a public nuisance per the Village of Broadview Code of ordinances or State
Statutes.
c. The applicant or mobile food vendor's operation has or likely would endanger the health, safety, and welfare of the residents, businessowners,
and visitors to the Village.
d. The proposed operation is in violation of any Federal, State, or local laws including, but not limited to, the provisions of this Code and the
Cook County Code of Ordinances pertaining to food, fire prevention, public health or safety.
2. The provisions of this section are not exclusive. This section shall not preclude the enforcement of any other provisions of this Code or
County, State and Federal laws, regulations, rules, and ordinances.
G. Appeal Rights:
1. A licensee or mobile food vendor applicant shall have the option to appeal an adverse decision of the Building Commissioner to the
Corporate Authorities. Such appeals must be in writing with a copy of the adverse decision attached thereto and the licensee or the mobile
food vendor applicant must state the reason he or she believes this decision to be in error. The appeal shall be filed with the Village of
Broadview - Village Clerk's Office no later than fourteen (14) calendar days after the issuance of the adverse decision. A failure to timely
appeal and attach a copy of the decision shall be grounds for the appeal to be dismissed with prejudice. The decision of the Corporate
Authorities is final.
H. Violations:
1. Any mobile food vendor or mobile food preparer shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) and not more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation.
2. Each day of a continuing violation shall constitute a separate violation and a penalty of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00)
per day may be assessed for each day the violation continues.
3. Pending a hearing pursuant to title 1, chapter 13 of this Code, the Building Commissioner shall be authorized to suspend the license of the
mobile food vendor and the mobile food vendor shall cease its operations pending the outcome of the hearing. (Ord. 2017-133, 9-18-2017)
Chapter 7
OFFENSIVE, UNWHOLESOME BUSINESSES AND ESTABLISHMENTS
4-7-1: UNWHOLESOME BUSINESSES PROHIBITED1:
It shall be unlawful to establish any unwholesome business, or any business or factory causing noxious odors within the Village or within one mile
of the Village limits. (1987 Code)
4-7-2: TREATMENT OF METALS:
4-7-2-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to engage in any business in which nitric acid, muriatic acid, sulfuric acid or similar chemicals are used in the treatment of
metals without having first secured a license therefor. (1987 Code)
4-7-2-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE2:
Application for license shall be made in full compliance with the general provisions of Title 3, Chapter 1 of this Code and shall designate the kinds
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 108/387
and quantities of such chemicals to be stored on the premises. (1987 Code)
4-7-2-3: REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS:
A. Storage And Ventilation: All chemicals referred to herein shall be safely stored in adequate containers labeled and used only for such
chemicals, and all rooms in which such chemicals are stored or used shall be properly vented and ventilated so that an adequate supply of
fresh air is present at all working hours.
B. Excessive Fumes: It shall be unlawful to permit the escape of sulfuric acid fumes or of any harmful fumes, in quantities sufficient to be
noticeable or an annoyance to the inhabitants of any building in the Village. (1987 Code)
4-7-2-4: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
The Bureau of Fire Prevention shall make or cause to be made all inspections necessary to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this
Section 4-7-2. (1987 Code)
4-7-3: FOUNDRIES, RENDERIES, SLAUGHTERHOUSES:
4-7-3-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to operate or maintain any foundry within the Village or any rendery, tallow chandlery, soap factory, tannery, packing plant or
slaughterhouse within the Village or within one mile of the Village limits without having secured a license therefor. (1987 Code)
4-7-3-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE, ISSUANCE:
Application for license shall be made in writing to the Village Clerk, but no such license shall be issued except upon the express order of the
Village Board of Trustees. (1987 Code)
4-7-3-3: LOCATION:
A. Frontage Consents Required In Residential District: It shall be unlawful to establish any factory or establishment mentioned herein in any place
where a majority of the premises within a radius of five hundred feet (500') are used for residence purposes without the consent of the owners
of two-thirds (2/3) of all the premises within such radius. Such frontage consents must be obtained and filed with the Clerk before a license will
be issued.
B. Zoning Requirements Take Precedence: The provisions of this Section shall not be construed to permit the establishment of any factory or
place of business in any location where such factory or place of business is prohibited by the zoning regulations3. (1987 Code)
4-7-4: PAINT SPRAYING:
4-7-4-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to operate any manufacturing or other business in which paint spraying is done or paint spraying equipment is used without
having first secured a license therefor. (1987 Code)
4-7-4-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
All applications for the licenses required herein shall be made in writing to the Village Clerk and shall contain in addition to the information
required by the general provisions of Title 3, Chapter 1 of this Code, a statement of the paint spraying equipment and the location thereof. (1987
Code)
4-7-4-3: FIRE REGULATIONS:
A. Use In Fireproof Room Required: No paint spraying equipment shall be maintained or used in any frame building or in any nonfireproof building
unless such equipment is maintained and used only in a fireproof room equipped with automatic fire doors.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 109/387
B. Refuse And Rubbish: No rubbish or refuse shall be allowed to accumulate upon the premises, and all such rubbish or refuse shall be collected
not less frequently than once every twenty four (24) hours, and either removed from the premises and disposed of in a manner complying with
the law or stored in fireproof containers with an adequate fireproof cover. Such cover shall always be kept closed unless when necessary to
take out to dispose of such refuse. (1987 Code)
4-7-4-4: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
The Fire Chief shall make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to see to the enforcement of this Section 4-7-4. (1987
Code)
4-7-5: RECLAIMING INDUSTRIAL SOLVENTS:
4-7-5-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of reclaiming industrial solvents including carbon tetrachloride, naphtha, toluol, trichlorethylene, acetone,
butyl acetate and mixtures of the above or other coal tar and petroleum hydrocarbons, without first having obtained a license so to do. (1987
Code)
4-7-5-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Any person who desires to engage in the business set forth herein within the corporate limits, shall make application therefor in writing to the
Village Clerk who shall refer such application to the Fire Chief for investigation. (1987 Code)
4-7-5-3: INVESTIGATION, ISSUANCE OF LICENSE, LICENSE FEE:
The Fire Chief, upon receipt of the application, shall investigate the person requesting the license, and if after such investigation, no good cause
for refusing its issuance is shown, it shall be issued by the President and Board of Trustees upon the payment by the applicant of the license fee
as set forth in Section 3-1A-1 of this Code. (1987 Code)
Footnote 1: See Section 3-1-10 of this Code, and Section 4-3-1 of this Title.
Footnote 2: See Section 3-1A-2 of this Code.
Footnote 3: See Title 10 of this Code.
Chapter 8
PET SHOPS
4-8-1: LICENSE REQUIRED, APPLICATION1:
It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of dealer in birds, cats, dogs or other household pets in the village without first having obtained a
license therefor. Application for such license shall be made to the village clerk. (1987 Code)
4-8-2: PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
Premises used for the purposes enumerated herein shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be thoroughly cleaned at least once
each day and shall be kept well ventilated. No refuse shall be allowed to accumulate thereon for a longer period than twenty four (24) hours.
(1987 Code)
4-8-3: DISEASED ANIMALS:
Any diseased animal on such premises shall be kept in separate quarters so that there shall be no danger of a spread of any disease from one
animal to another. (1987 Code)
4-8-4: INSPECTIONS:
The village sanitarian shall make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this
chapter. (1987 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 110/387
Chapter 9
HOMES AND INSTITUTIONS1
4-9-1: DEFINITION:
The word "home" is hereby defined to be any institution, place or facility used for the reception or care of three (3) or more infants or children,
apart from their parents; and any institution used for the care of persons who are dependent or not capable of properly caring for themselves. The
term "home" shall be understood to include homes for the aged or infirm, orphan asylums, half orphan asylums, refuges and shelters. (1987
Code)
4-9-2: LICENSE REQUIRED2:
It shall be unlawful for any person other than the regularly constituted authorities of the United States, the County or any association or institution
which has been accredited, certified or licensed by the State pursuant to an act of the legislature to regulate the treatment and control of
dependent, neglected and delinquent children, to conduct or operate any home within the Village without first obtaining a license therefor. (1987
Code)
4-9-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
The applicant shall file an application with the Village Clerk stating the following:
A. The proposed location of the home;
B. The purpose for which it is to be conducted or operated;
C. The accommodations for the inmates thereof;
D. The nature and kind of care;
E. Instructions or benefits given or proposed to be given;
F. The name and address of the party or parties conducting, managing or maintaining the home;
G. The name of the superintendent or person in charge of the home; and
H. The name and address of the attending physician. (1987 Code)
4-9-4: INVESTIGATION, INSPECTION:
A. Investigation Of Applicant: The application must be filed with the Chief of Police who shall make or cause to be made, a strict inquiry into the
facts set out in such application to determine whether such home is or is intended to be so conducted as to afford proper accommodations for
the care of the persons received or proposed to be received, and that the superintendent in charge thereof is a person of good moral
character and has sufficient experience to conduct such home.
B. Building Inspection: Every home shall at all times be opened to inspection by the Chief of Police, the Fire Chief and the Building Commissioner
whenever and as often as they shall deem proper. (1987 Code)
4-9-5: LICENSE FEE EXEMPTION:
Homes which are operated without charge being made for care of inmates shall be exempt from the payment of a license fee. Operators of such
homes shall file an affidavit with application stating that no charge is to be made for the care of inmates. This affidavit shall be investigated as to
its credibility by the Chief of Police and upon his recommendation to the Village Trustees, the license will be issued without charge. Such
exemption shall continue only for the duration of the license period. (1987 Code)
4-9-6: FRONTAGE CONSENTS REQUIRED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 111/387
No license shall be issued to any person to operate or conduct a home in any block in which two-thirds (2/3) of the buildings on the street are
devoted exclusively to residential purposes unless a majority of the property owners on both sides of the street in such block consent in writing of
the operation of such home. (1987 Code)
4-9-7: RECORDS:
Every home shall keep a complete record of each inmate showing the date admitted to the home, name, address, sex, social status, date of
discharge, name and address of persons from whom received. (1987 Code)
4-9-8: BUILDING REQUIREMENTS:
A. Compliance With Building And Fire Regulations: Any building used as a home shall comply with the building code3 and fire regulations of the
Village4.
B. Isolation Room For Contagious Diseases: Every home shall be provided with a suitable room or rooms, to be used for the isolation of cases of
contagious, infectious, epidemic or communicable diseases that may be found in the home, until such time as the person suffering from such
contagious disease is removed. This room shall have separate toilet facilities and washstands. (1987 Code)
4-9-9: PENALTIES:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be subject to a fine as provided in Section 1-4-1 of this Code; that in the event of
conviction of any such person for a violation of any of the provisions of this Chapter relating to the safety and accommodations of the inmates, it
shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to close such home and to cause its vacation pending the repairs, alterations or additions necessary to
make it safe and proper for the occupancy of its inmates. (1987 Code)
Chapter 10
DAY NURSERIES1
4-10-1: DEFINITION:
For the purpose of this Chapter the term "day nursery" shall mean any childcare facility receiving one or more children for care during part or all of
a day between six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and shall include facilities commonly called "childcare centers", "day nurseries",
"nursery schools", kindergartens", and "playgroups", with or without stated educational purposes. The term "day nursery" does not include:
A. Bona fide kindergartens or nursery schools operating under the auspices of established public or private boards of education;
B. Bona fide kindergartens or nursery schools approved by the superintendent of public instruction or the school districts in which such
kindergartens or nursery schools are located; or
C. Those facilities operated in connection with a shopping center or shopping service where transient children are received while parents are
shopping on the premises. (1987 Code)
4-10-2: PERMIT REQUIRED, APPLICATION:
Every person desiring to operate a day nursery in the Village shall obtain a permit therefor before commencing operation and shall make
application therefor to the Village Clerk on forms furnished by him. The application shall contain such information as may be required by the
Clerk. (1987 Code)
4-10-3: INVESTIGATION, INSPECTIONS:
Upon receipt of an application for a permit required herein, the Village Clerk shall refer it to the Health Department for investigation. The Health
Department shall inspect the premises where in the day nursery is proposed as to the following conditions:
A. The operation and conduct of the facility and the responsibility it assumes for childcare;
B. The character, suitability and qualifications of the applicant and other persons directly responsible for the care and welfare of children served;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 112/387
C. The general financial ability and competence of the applicant to provide necessary care for children and to maintain prescribed standards;
D. The adequacy of the number of individuals required to ensure adequate supervision and care of the children;
E. The appropriateness, safety, cleanliness and general adequacy of the premises, including maintenance of adequate fire prevention and health
standards in conformance to State laws;
F. Provisions for food, clothing, education opportunities, program, equipment and individual supplies to assure the healthy physical, mental and
spiritual development of the children served; and
G. Discipline of the children.
The Health Department and the Fire Chief shall make periodic inspections of all premises used as day nurseries and shall issue such orders
as they deem necessary to maintain health standards and fire protection. (1987 Code)
4-10-4: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT, TERM, APPEALS:
If, after investigation, the Health Department recommends the issuance of the permit, the Village Clerk shall issue such permit which shall be
valid for the Village license year.
Any person aggrieved by the failure of the Health Department to approve the issuance of a day nursery permit may appeal to the Board of
Trustees whose decision shall be final. (1987 Code)
4-10-5: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
Any permit issued under the terms of this Chapter may be revoked for the following reasons:
A. Consistent failure to maintain health standards prescribed.
B. Violation of the terms of the license.
C. Furnishing or making false or misleading information in the application. (1987 Code)
4-10-6: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The Health Department of the Village shall prescribe rules and regulations pertaining to the operation and standards of day nurseries. (1987
Code)
Footnote 1: See Title 3, Chapter 1 of this Code and Chapter 9 of this Title.
Chapter 11
CEMETERIES
4-11-1: BOUNDARIES OF EXISTING CEMETERIES ESTABLISHED:
The boundaries of all cemeteries within the limits of the Village are hereby fixed at the enclosures now surrounding such cemeteries; and the
boundaries of such cemeteries as are now enclosed shall be the same as now appear on record in the maps, plats, deeds or in the letter of
application of such cemeteries. (1987 Code)
4-11-2: INTERMENT RULES AND REGULATIONS1:
No corpse shall be interred in any place within the limits of the Village not actually used as a cemetery on September 17, 1934, or lying within the
enclosure of a cemetery not established on or before that day, except as hereinafter provided.
It shall be lawful to inter dead bodies within the limits of any cemetery established and used as a cemetery on September 17, 1934, under such
rules and regulations as may, from time to time, be made by the President and the Board of Trustees; but the burial of any corpse outside of such
limits and within the Village shall be deemed a violation of this Section. (1987 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 113/387
Chapter 12
GARAGE SALES
4-12-1: DEFINED:
"Garage Sale" means an occasional sale of used or surplus household goods, furnishings, wares and other items of personal property owned by
the occupier of the residence where such sale is held, and includes sales commonly known as basement sales, house sales, yard sales, attic
sales, rummage sales, estate sales or other similar occasional sales from residentially zoned premises. (Ord. 2001-20, 9-10-2001)
4-12-2: ITEMS PROHIBITED:
The sale of the following items is prohibited at a garage sale: food; drink; animals; bulk sales of any item; multiple new items of the same
description; consigned merchandise; junk or antique items sold as a business activity by a person involved therein as a junk or antique dealer.
Items purchased for intentional sale or resale may not be sold at such a sale. (Ord. 2001-20, 9-10-2001)
4-12-3: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or allow a "garage sale" as defined herein on premises zoned or used for residential purposes
without first obtaining a permit to conduct such sale. The applicant must be the owner or occupant of the residence where the sale is to be held,
and the applicant shall apply for and obtain such a permit from the village clerk at least seventy two (72) hours in advance of the date of such
sale. There shall be a ten dollar ($10.00) fee for such permit. The permit shall list the name of the applicant and the address at which the sale is
to be held. Each permit shall be prominently displayed on the premises covered by the permit in such a manner as to be easily visible to persons
passing by the premises on a public street. (Ord. 2001-20, 9-10-2001)
4-12-4: LENGTH AND FREQUENCY OF SALES:
Garage sales shall be permitted for not more than three (3) consecutive days between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00)
P.M. of each day. Not more than three (3) garage sales shall be conducted on the same premises within any calendar year. (Ord. 2001-20, 9-10-
2001)
4-12-5: LOCATION OF SALE:
All activity associated with the garage sale shall be limited to the property specified on the permit. Additionally, no garage, no sidewalk, street,
alley, or parkway may be hindered, obstructed, or occupied by any items for sale or any related garage sale activity. (Ord. 2001-20, 9-10-2001)
4-12-6: SIGNS:
No more than two (2) signs advertising the garage/yard sale may be posted on the lot where the sale is being held, and the size of such signs
shall not exceed two feet by three feet (2' x 3'). Such signs shall not be posted for more than four (4) days. (Ord. 2002-02, 1-14-2002)
4-12-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. Each day that such a violation occurs or continues shall be deemed to constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2001-20, 9-10-2001)
Chapter 13
VACANT PROPERTY
4-13-1: DECLARATION OF POLICY:
The purpose of this chapter is to protect the public health, safety, and welfare by:
A. Establishing a program for identification, registration, and maintenance of buildings which are or become vacant on and after the effective date
of this chapter.
B. Determining the responsibilities of the owners of record of vacant buildings.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 114/387
C. Providing for administration, enforcement, including the abatement of public nuisances, and imposition of penalties. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-2: OTHER ORDINANCES:
This chapter shall not be construed to prevent the enforcement of other applicable ordinances, codes, legislation, and regulations prescribing
standards other than are provided herein, and in the event of conflict, the most restrictive shall apply. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-3: DEFINITIONS:
Unless otherwise expressly stated or clearly indicated by context, the following terms shall, for the purpose of this chapter, have the meanings
indicated in this section:
BOARDED BUILDING: A building which has had in a manner intended to be temporary or permanent, any or all openings, which openings are
windows or doors which were present for the purpose of light, ventilation or egress, some material whether opaque, solid or transparent, affixed to
such openings, from the interior or exterior of the building, for the purpose of securing or preventing access or damage to the building or its
components.
BUILDING: Any structure occupied or intended for supporting or sheltering any occupancy.
DANGEROUS OR UNSAFE BUILDING: All buildings or structures that are found to pose a danger to the life, health, property or safety of the
public by not providing minimum safeguards to protect or warn the public in the event of a fire, or because such structure contains unsafe
equipment, or is so damaged, decayed, dilapidated, structurally unsafe or of such faulty or incomplete construction or unstable, that partial or
complete collapse or systems failures are possible.
DIRECTOR: The building commissioner, or his/her designee.
OWNER: Any person, agent, operator, firm, or corporation having a legal or equitable interest in the property, including lienholders of record; or
recorded in the official records of the state, county, or municipality as holding title to the property; or otherwise having control of the property,
including the guardian of the estate of any such person, and the executor or administrator of the estate of such person if ordered to take
possession of real property by a court.
PERSON: Includes a corporation, a partnership, or other entity, as well as an individual.
PREMISES: A lot, plot or parcel of land including any structure thereon.
UNOCCUPIED BUILDING: A building or portion thereof which lacks the habitual presence of human beings who have a legal right to be on the
premises, including buildings ordered vacated by the director pursuant to authority granted by this code. This definition does not include a building
that is actively for sale, lease or rent, as evidenced by a contractual agreement between the homeowner of record and a licensed real estate
agent or brokerage, and performance of sufficient maintenance that the building or the property on which it sits does not become a nuisance.
VACANT BUILDINGS: Any building that has not been legally occupied for a consecutive period of one month unless one of the following is true:
A. The building is the subject of an active building permit for repair or rehabilitation and the owner is progressing diligently to complete the
repair or rehabilitation.
B. The building meets all codes, is not in a state of disrepair or deterioration, is ready for occupancy, and is actively being offered for sale,
lease or rent and is actively being maintained and monitored by the owner.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the building is still not legally occupied within thirty (30) days after completion of the repairs as specified in
subsection A of this definition or within sixty (60) days after the director has determined that the building has met all codes as specified in
subsection B of this definition, the director may declare the building a vacant building. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-4: DETERMINATION:
A. After the effective date of this chapter, the director shall evaluate all buildings in the village believed to be unoccupied on the effective date of
this chapter and make a determination for each as to whether the building is a "vacant building" within the meaning of section 4-13-3 of this
chapter. The director may determine that a building which meets any of the criteria set forth in this chapter is not to be regulated under this
chapter for a stated period, if upon consideration of reliable, substantiated and sufficient evidence, the director determines that regulation of
the building under this chapter would not serve the public health, welfare, and safety and makes written findings in support of this decision.
The determination shall be in writing and shall state the factual basis for the determination.
B. For buildings the director determines to be "vacant buildings", the director shall send notice of this written determination with the factual
findings to the last taxpayer of record listed on the most recent Cook County tax roll and if notice is to a lienholder then to the address of the
lienholder. Said notice of determination shall be sent first class United States mail, with proper postage prepaid. Failure of delivery shall not
excuse a person from complying with this chapter. The director may also personally serve or cause personal service of the notice of
determination. Any person making such service shall execute an affidavit attesting to the facts of service. The director shall maintain an
affidavit of such mailing for each notice of determination sent.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 115/387
C. The notice shall specify a date and time on which the owner may voluntarily allow for a code compliance inspection of the interior of the vacant
building and surrounding yards and property to determine the extent of compliance with village property, building, health, fire, and plumbing
codes.
D. For residential buildings, if a voluntary code compliance inspection is scheduled by the owner and a plan to maintain the structure, yards and
property is submitted by the owner to and approved by the village, no costs for the code compliance inspection will be assessed by the village.
E. For all residential buildings in which a voluntary code compliance inspection is not scheduled by the owner and for all commercial and
industrial buildings, all village inspection fees and any costs and fees associated with all actions to gain entry to the structure, yards and
property and any costs and fees associated in correcting code violations will be the responsibility of the owner. Any unpaid costs and fees
shall be recaptured by a lien upon the premises.
F. The notice shall contain a statement of the obligations of the owner of a building determined to be vacant, a copy of the registration form the
owner is required to file pursuant to this chapter, and a notice of the owner's right to appeal the director's determination. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-
2010)
4-13-5: APPEAL OF DETERMINATION:
A. An owner of a building determined by the director to be a vacant building as provided for in this chapter may appeal that determination to the
village president. Such appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed with the village president within fifteen (15) days of the date of mailing of the
notice of determination. The filing of an appeal stays the owner's obligation to register his building as required by this chapter. The appeal
shall contain a complete statement of the reasons the owner disputes the director's determination, shall set forth specific facts in support
thereof, and shall include all evidence the owner relies upon to support the appeal. The village president or the village president's designee
shall decide the appeal on the basis of facts presented by the owner in his or her written appeal and the director's written determination.
B. The burden is upon the owner to present sufficient evidence to persuade the village president that had the evidence been known to the director
at the time the director made the determination, the director would more likely than not have determined that the subject building was not a
"vacant building" within the meaning of this chapter.
C. The village president or his designee shall send written notice of a decision to the owner within thirty (30) days of his or her receipt of the
appeal. The village president may, but is not required to, seek additional information from the owner. The village president may, upon written
notice thereof to the owner, take no more than ten (10) additional days, to decide the appeal if he or she determines that such additional time
is required for consideration of the appeal. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-6: REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
The owner of a building who knows, or from all the facts and circumstances should know, that his or her building is or has become a "vacant
building" within the meaning of this chapter after the effective date of this chapter, or the owner of a building, which the director determines at any
time to be a "vacant building", or the owner of a building whose appeal from the director's determination has been denied by the village president
shall take the actions provided for in this section within fifteen (15) days after either the date of director's notice of determination or occurrence of
the facts that would cause a reasonable person to believe that the building was a "vacant building", or denial of the appeal, whichever is
applicable. Registration does not exonerate the owner from compliance with all applicable codes and ordinances, including this chapter, nor does
it preclude any of the actions the village is authorized to take pursuant to this chapter or elsewhere in this code or as allowable by Illinois or
federal law. In such case, the owner shall do the following:
A. Register the building with the director, on a form provided by the director and pay the annual nonprorated vacant building registration fee as
provided in this chapter. The form shall include, as a minimum, the name, street address, and telephone number of the owner; the case name
and number of any litigation pending concerning or affecting the building, including, but not limited to, bankruptcy, foreclosure and other cases;
and the name, street address, and telephone number of all persons with any legal interest, including lienholders, in the building or the
premises. The form shall require the owner to identify a natural person twenty one (21) years of age or older who maintains a permanent
address in Cook County, Illinois, to accept service on behalf of the owner with respect to any notices the director sends pursuant to this
chapter or service of process in any proceeding commenced to enforce any provision of this chapter, and file with the director on the
registration form, the name, address, telephone number, of said person. A street address is required. A post office box is not an acceptable
address; and
B. Renew the vacant building registration each year on the anniversary date of the first filing for the time the building remains vacant and pay the
annual fee as provided in this chapter; and
C. File an amended registration within fifteen (15) days of any change in the information contained in the annual registration. A new registration is
required for any change in ownership whatsoever.
D. The owner executing a form to indicate his or her "acceptance of notice by posting" consenting to service of notices sent or required to be sent,
pursuant to this chapter, by posting on the building if the owner fails to renew the registration, if required, or maintain as current with the
director the information required regarding the person designated to accept notice and service of process.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 116/387
E. The owner shall allow for a code compliance inspection of the interior of the vacant building and shall be subject to village costs and fees
outlined in this chapter within fifteen (15) days of the registration or renewal registration. Such inspection will determine the extent of
compliance with all applicable village property, building, electrical, plumbing, fire and similar codes.
F. Obtain liability insurance and maintain such insurance for as long as the building is vacant, and file evidence of such insurance with the
director, as follows:
For a vacant residential building of:
1 to 3 units $ 500,000.00
4 to 11 units 750,000.00
12 to 48 units 1,000,000.00
More than 48 units 2,000,000.00
For a vacant manufacturing, industrial, storage, or nonresidential commercial building 2,000,000.00
The director may waive or reduce the required amount of liability insurance in the director's discretion. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-7: VACANT BUILDING PLAN:
At the time a building is registered as required herein, the owner shall submit a vacant building plan. The director may prescribe a form for the
plan. If the owner fails to submit the plan as provided for by this section, the director may determine the plan. The plan shall contain the following
as a minimum:
A. A plan of action to repair any doors, windows, or other openings which are boarded up or otherwise secured by any means other than
conventional methods used in the design of the building or permitted for new construction or similar type. The proposed repair shall result in
openings being secured by conventional methods used in the design of the building or by methods permitted for new construction of similar
type with board removed. The owner shall maintain the building in an enclosed and secure state until the building is reoccupied or made
available for immediate occupancy. If the owner demonstrates that securing of the building will provide adequate protection to the public, the
director may waive the requirement of an enclosure.
B. For buildings and premises thereof that the director determines as being or containing public nuisances, as defined in this code, then the
vacant building plan shall contain a plan of action to remedy such public nuisance(s).
C. A time schedule identifying a date of commencement of repair and date of completion of repair for each improperly secured opening and
nuisance identified by the director.
D. When the owner proposes to demolish the vacant building, then the owner shall submit a plan and time schedule for such demolition.
E. A plan of action to maintain the building and premises thereof in conformance with this chapter.
F. A plan of action, with a time schedule, identifying the date the building will be habitable and occupied or offered for occupancy or sale. The time
schedule shall include date(s) of commencement and completion of all action required to achieve habitability and shall be based on the time
period as determined by the director, to achieve such compliance.
G. All premises upon which unoccupied or vacant buildings are located and the exteriors shall at all times be maintained in compliance with this
code.
H. Exterior lighting according to standards established by the director.
I. On written notice of the director, provide bonded, licensed, and insured security guard service at the building between the hours of three o'clock
(3:00) P.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. Such service to remain in place until the director gives written notice that the service is no longer
required. Such service shall be required when the director makes a written determination that the vacant building constitutes a fire hazard, is
otherwise dangerous to human life or the public welfare, involves illegal or improper use, occupancy, or maintenance, under such conditions
that boarding and securing the building are insufficient to prevent the actual or threatened harm.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 117/387
J. Affixed to any building which is boarded, a sign, no smaller than two feet by two feet (2' x 2') and compliant with the village's sign ordinance,
title 9, chapter 8A of this code, and providing the following information: the name, address, and telephone number of the owner, and in
addition, for buildings that are the subject of a foreclosure action, the name, address, and telephone number of the plaintiff and the plaintiff's
attorney, if any, in the foreclosure action. The sign must be placed so that its message is legible from the public way. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-8: APPROVAL OF PLAN:
A. The director shall review the proposed vacant building plan in accordance with the standards below. The director shall send notice to the owner
of the vacant building of the director's determination.
B. In considering the appropriateness of a vacant building plan, the director shall include the following standards in his or her consideration and
shall make written findings as to each:
1. The purposes of this chapter and intent of the village board to minimize the time a building is boarded or otherwise vacant.
2. The effect of the building and the proposed plan on adjoining property.
3. The length of time the building has been vacant.
4. The presence of any public nuisances on the property.
5. The likelihood that the plan or portion(s) thereof will prevent or ameliorate the condition it is designed to address. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-9: MODIFY VACANT BUILDING PLAN:
The director shall, upon notice to the vacant building owner, have the right to modify the vacant building plan by modifying the dates of
performance, the proposed methods of action, or by imposing additional requirements consistent with this chapter that the director deems
necessary to protect the public health, safety, or welfare. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-10: FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH PLAN:
Failure to have an approved plan within thirty (30) days of filing the registration form or failure to comply with the approved plan shall constitute a
violation of this chapter subjecting the owner of the building to penalties as provided in this chapter and to any remedies the village may avail
itself of as provided for herein and elsewhere in this code or by Illinois law, including, but limited to, an action to compel correction of property
maintenance violations and/or the correction of property maintenance violations by the village, and/or its designees, with the owner being liable
for any and all fees for such action. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-11: OTHER ENFORCEMENT:
The registration of a vacant building shall not preclude action by the village to demolish or to take other action against the building pursuant to
other provisions of this chapter, this code or 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-31-1. This shall also include the right of the village to secure and
take remedial actions to the building and the premises when it is in the best interest of the public safety and welfare. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-12: CERTIFICATION:
A certificate of code compliance for vacant buildings issued by the building department, and payment in full of all fines and fees imposed pursuant
to this chapter are required prior to any occupancy of a vacant building. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-13: TIME RESTRICTIONS:
It is the policy of the village that boarding is a temporary solution to prevent unauthorized entry into a vacant building and that boarded buildings
are a public nuisance. A vacant building may not remain boarded longer than fourteen (14) days unless an extension of that time is part of a plan
approved by the director. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-14: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES:
A. Any person found to have violated any provision of this chapter shall be subject to the general penalty of this code, in addition to any other
legal or equitable remedies available to the village. Such other remedies include, but are not limited to, injunctive relief, application to a court
of competent jurisdiction for a receiver, demolition, or condemnation, contracting for the repair or purchase of the premises, or foreclosure of
any lien the village may have thereon. Any expenses incurred by the village as enumerated above shall be assessed against the building, and
shall serve as a lien on the property.
B. A separate and distinct offense shall be committed each day on which such person or persons shall violate the provisions of this chapter.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 118/387
C. The village may enforce this chapter in a system of administrative adjudication or through the circuit court of Cook County.
D. Nothing herein contained shall prohibit the village from immediately condemning, as provided for in this code, a building, or taking other
immediate action upon a determination that the building is a public nuisance or poses an imminent danger to the occupants of the building, or
the public health, safety and welfare. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-15: SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL; REGISTRATION AND RENEWAL FEE:
The registration and renewal fee for each registered single-family residential building shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), the "base
registration fee". Provided however that the owner shall be charged a fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) on the subsequent renewal periods in
which any vacant residential, single-family building is in violation of any provision of this code. However, if the owner of a single-family residential
building can show to the satisfaction of the director at the time of renewal that the building is in full compliance with this code then such renewal
shall revert to the base registration fee. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-16: MULTI-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL OR COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS; REGISTRATION AND RENEWAL FEE:
The registration and renewal fee for each registered multi-family residential or commercial building shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00), the
"base registration fee". Provided however that the owner shall be charged a fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) on the subsequent renewal
periods in which any vacant multi-family residential or commercial building is in violation of any provision of this code. However, if the owner of a
multi-family residential or commercial building can show to the satisfaction of the director at the time of renewal that the building is in full
compliance with this code then such renewal shall revert to the base registration fee. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-17: INDUSTRIAL BUILDINGS; REGISTRATION AND RENEWAL FEE:
The registration and renewal fee for each registered industrial building shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), the "base registration fee".
Provided however that the owner shall be charged a fee of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) on the subsequent renewal periods in which any
vacant industrial building is in violation of any provision of this code. If the owner of an industrial building can show to the satisfaction of the
director at the time renewal is required that the building is in full compliance with this code then such renewal shall revert to the base registration
fee. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
Chapter 14
LIENS
4-14-1: NOTICE OF LIEN:
A. Removal Cost: If the village elects to incur a removal cost under this title, then that cost is a lien upon the underlying parcel. To perfect such a
lien, the village must, within one year after the removal cost is incurred, file notice of lien in the office of the recorder in Cook County. The
notice must consist of a sworn statement setting out: 1) a description of the underlying parcel that sufficiently identifies the parcel; 2) the
amount of the removal cost; and 3) the date or dates when the removal cost was incurred by the village. If, for any one parcel, the village
engaged in any removal activity on more than one occasion during the course of one year, then the village may combine any or all of the costs
of each of those activities into a single notice of lien.
B. Notice: The removal cost is not a lien on the underlying parcel unless a notice is personally served on, or sent by certified mail to, the person to
whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes on the property for the taxable year immediately preceding the removal activities. The notice
must be delivered or sent after the removal activities have been performed, and it must: 1) state the substance of this chapter; and 2) identify
the underlying parcel, by common description; and 3) describe the removal activity.
C. Payment Of The Lien Cost: Upon payment of the lien cost by the owner of the underlying parcel, after notice of lien has been filed, the village
(or its agent) shall release the lien, and the release may be filed of record by the owner at his or her sole expense as in the case of filing notice
of lien.
D. Illinois Municipal Code: The provisions of the Illinois municipal code, specifically section 11-20-15, shall be followed and shall apply to all liens
filed hereunder.
E. Foreclosure Of Lien: Subsequent to the filing of the above described lien, the village may cause to be filed a complaint for foreclosure of such
lien, or upon becoming a defendant in a pending lawsuit affecting the premises or real estate, by answer to the complaint or in the nature of an
intervening petition or cross complaint, the village may proceed in its corporate name to foreclose such lien. An action to foreclose a lien under
this title must be commenced within two (2) years after the date of filing notice of lien. The property subject to a lien arising under this chapter
shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to pay the monies owing the village. (Ord. 13-36, 5-
20-2013)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 119/387
4-14-2: PRIORITY LIEN:
A. Priority Lien: The priority lien procedure described in this section shall apply only to costs incurred for activities performed on abandoned
residential properties, as defined in chapter 13, "Vacant Property", of this title and is an alternative to the traditional lien authorized by section
4-14-1 of this chapter. If a bill sent pursuant to section 4-14-1 of this chapter is not paid in full within thirty (30) days of the date of the bill, the
village shall have the authority to file and record a priority lien against the property, pursuant to section 11-20-15.1 of the Illinois municipal
code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-15.1, in the following manner:
1. Notice Of Lien: The village or the person performing the service by authority of the village, in its, his or her own name, may file a notice of a
priority lien in the office of the recorder of deeds in the county in which the real estate is located. The notice of lien shall be filed within one
year after the cost and expense is incurred. If, for any one property, the village engaged in any nuisance abatement activity described in
section 98.03 on more than one occasion during the course of one year, then the village may combine any or all of the costs of those
