for disconnection of any alarm system, the Village shall have no liability for such action. (Ord. 2014-01, 1-8-2014)
Title 15
QUASI-CRIMINAL OFFENSES
Chapter 1
GENERAL PENALTY AND JUDICIAL REVIEW
15-1-1: PENALTY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 369/387
Whenever in this title, any act which is an offense, is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful, the violation of any such provision of this
title shall be punished by a fine not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), unless otherwise stated,
and every day that such violation continues and exists shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. All violations shall be prosecuted under the
provisions of the code hearing department as defined in title 1, chapter 13 of this code at the village hall or such other place as designated by the
corporate authorities.
A penalty imposed for violation of this title may also include or consist of, at the discretion of the hearing officer as defined in title 1, chapter 13 of
this code, a requirement that the defendant perform some reasonable public service work such as, but not limited to, the picking up of litter in
public parks or along public highways or the maintenance of public facilities. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-1-2: PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY:
A parent or legal guardian is liable for any and all fines assessed against an unemancipated minor who resides with such parent or legal
guardian. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-1-3: JUDGMENT:
Any fine or any penalty imposed in accordance with this title and remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust, administrative
remedies created under this title and the conclusion of any judicial review procedures shall be a debt due and owing, the village and, as such,
may be collected in accordance with the applicable law. Payment in full of any fine or penalty resulting from an offense or violation under this title
shall constitute a final disposition of that violation. A default in the payment of a fine or penalty or any installment of a fine or penalty may be
collected by any means authorized for the collection of monetary judgments. The village attorney may retain attorneys and private collection
agents for the purpose of collecting any default in payment of any fine or penalty or installment of that fine or penalty. Any fees or costs incurred
by the village or any attorney fees shall be charged to the defendant. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-1-4: JUDICIAL REVIEW:
Judicial review of final determinations and final administrative decisions regarding violations under this title shall be subject to the provisions of
the administrative review law as is set forth in 735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq., incorporated herein by reference. (Ord. 09-48, 10-
19-2009)

Chapter 5
ANIMALS
15-5-1: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
No person shall cruelly treat any animal in the village in any way. Any person who inhumanely beats, underfeeds, fails to provide a clean water
source for drinking, fails to provide adequate shelter, overloads or abandons any animal shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter. (Ord.
09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-5-2: DANGEROUS OR VICIOUS ANIMAL; DEFINITION:
A. Any animal that when unprovoked: 1) inflicts bites on or attacks a human being or domestic animal either on public or private property; or 2) in
a vicious or terrorizing manner approaches any person in an apparent attitude of attack on any public way or in any public place;
B. Any animal with a known propensity, tendency or disposition to attack without provocation, to cause injury or otherwise to endanger the safety
of human beings or domestic animals;
C. Any animal that attacks a human being or domestic animal without provocation; or
D. Any animal owned, harbored, trained or used for fighting against another animal or person. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-5-3: DANGEROUS OR VICIOUS ANIMAL; REQUIREMENTS:
A. Every dangerous or vicious animal allowed to be kept by state law shall have a license. In order to obtain a license for a dangerous or vicious
animal, the owner of the animal shall present to the health department proof that the owner has procured liability insurance in the amount of
one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00), issued by an insurer authorized to underwrite risks in this state, covering any damage or injury
which may be caused by the dangerous or vicious animal during the license period. The insurance policy shall contain a provision that the
health department will be notified thirty (30) days prior to any cancellation of the policy. Each license shall bear a different number.
B. The owner of the dangerous or vicious animal shall have the license number of the animal tattooed on the upper inner lip of the animal by a
licensed veterinarian.
C. The owner of the dangerous or vicious animal shall post a sign no smaller than twenty four inches (24") square, bearing the legend "Warning-
Dangerous Animal" in print no smaller than three inches (3") high, and the license number of the animal in print no smaller than one inch (1")
high. The sign shall be posted at the entry to the building in which the animal is kept, in such a way as to be visible from the nearest public
sidewalk.
D. The owner of a dangerous or vicious animal shall not allow the animal outside the owner's dwelling unless: 1) the animal is in a locked
enclosure secure on all sides and on the top against intrusion by domestic animals and humans other than the owner; or 2) the animal is
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 371/387
muzzled and under restraint and under the direct control of the owner. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-5-4: DANGEROUS OR VICIOUS ANIMAL; VIOLATIONS:
Any dangerous or vicious animal kept, harbored or maintained in violation of this chapter shall be subject to impoundment and destruction by the
health department. If a dangerous or vicious animal possessed, harbored, kept or maintained in violation of this chapter bites or inflicts any other
injury on any person other than its owner, the owner of the animal shall be subject to a fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Any person
who otherwise possesses, harbors, keeps or maintains a dangerous or vicious animal in violation of this chapter shall be subject to the general
penalty provision of section 15-1-1 of this title. The requirements of this section shall not apply to dogs owned by law enforcement agencies and
used in law enforcement work. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-5-5: DISTURBING THE PEACE:
It shall be unlawful to harbor or keep any animal which disturbs the peace by loud noises at any time of the day or night. Such an animal shall be
deemed a nuisance for the purposes of this chapter and this code. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-5-6: DISEASED ANIMALS:
No domestic animal afflicted with a contagious or infectious disease shall be allowed to run at large or to be exposed in any public place in the
village whereby the health of man or beast may be affected, nor shall such diseased animal be shipped or removed from the premises of the
owner thereof, except under the supervision of the health department or of the state veterinarian and no diseased animals shall be brought into
the village.
It is the duty of the health department to secure such disposition of any diseased animal and such treatment of affected premises as to prevent
the communication and spread of the contagion or infection, except in cases where the state veterinarian is empowered to act, and in all such
cases, the health department shall cooperate with the state veterinarian so far as such cooperation may be necessary to the protection of the
health of the citizens of the village.
All animals kept within the village shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. It shall be the duty of any owner or custodian of any
animals to report to the health officer the occurrence of any disease such as rabies, glanders or anthrax among those animals which is
transmissible to human beings. Any animal infected with such a disease shall be cared for or disposed of as provided in this chapter. (Ord. 09-48,
10-19-2009)
15-5-7: LICENSE REQUIRED, FEE:
Every person who owns, keeps or harbors a dog or cat, within the limits of the village shall, during the month of March of each year or within ten
(10) days of the date such dog or cat is acquired, report this fact to the village clerk-collector, together with the name, breed, color and sex of
every dog or cat so owned, kept or harbored by such person and shall pay to the clerk-collector as a yearly license fee, the sum of fifteen dollars
($15.00) for each dog or cat so owned, kept or harbored, regardless of sex, age, color or breed. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-5-8: TAGS REQUIRED:
Upon the payment of the fee the village clerk-collector shall furnish the owner or keeper of each dog so licensed with a license tag marked with
the initials BDT for dogs and BCT for cats which tags shall be numbered consecutively and shall be of a different design or pattern each year.
Every dog and cat so owned, kept or harbored within the limits of the village shall be provided by its owner or keeper with a leather or chain collar
to which the license tag shall be securely fastened. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-5-9: RABIES INOCULATION:
No license for any dog or cat shall be issued unless the owner thereof presents with his application for a license a certificate from a duly licensed
registered veterinarian showing that the dog or cat for which the license is sought has been inoculated within the past twelve (12) months with a
prophylactic serum to prevent rabies. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-5-10: MUZZLES OR LEASHES:
No owner of any dog within the limits of the village shall permit any such dog to leave the premises of the owner at any time unless the dog is
securely leashed or is muzzled in such manner as to fully prevent the dog from biting any person or animal. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-5-11: DEFECATING ON PUBLIC OR PRIVATE PROPERTY:
No person shall cause or permit any dog or cat owned by him to create a nuisance by defecating or urinating upon any public street, sidewalk or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 372/387
other place or upon any premises not owned or controlled by the person owning or keeping the dog or cat. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-5-12: IMPOUNDMENT:
A. Dogs: It is the duty of the chief of police, or any person designated by him, to capture and impound, either at a licensed pound within the village
or at one in close proximity to the village, each dog found at large off the premises of its owner and within the limits of the village, which is
without a muzzle, leash, collar or tag as required by this chapter.
B. Cats: It is the duty of the chief of police, or any person designated by him, to capture and impound, either at a licensed pound within the village
or at one in close proximity to the village, each cat found at large off the premises of its owner and within the limits of the village, which is
without collar and tag as required herein. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-5-13: REDEMPTION OF IMPOUNDED DOGS AND CATS:
A. Dogs: The chief of police, or any person or entity designated by him, shall promptly notify the owner of any dog so impounded, if the same can
be ascertained, and the owner may redeem the dog, provided the dog exhibits no evidence of disease, within five (5) days from the time of its
capture by providing proof of rabies inoculation and paying the license fee or fine as provided herein.
B. Cats: The chief of police, or any person or entity designated by him, shall promptly notify the owner of any cat so impounded, if the same can
be ascertained, and the owner may redeem the cat, provided the cat exhibits no evidence of disease, within five (5) days from the time of its
capture by providing proof of rabies inoculation and paying the license fee or fine as provided herein. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-5-14: DESTRUCTION OF UNREDEEMED AND VICIOUS DOGS AND CATS:
A. Dogs: It is the duty of the chief of police, or any person or entity designated by him, to destroy any dog unredeemed at the expiration of five (5)
days from the time of capture, or to provide for its donation to a licensed animal shelter facility, and it shall be lawful for the village police to kill
any vicious dog at large within the limits of the village which cannot safely be taken up and impounded. Any such destruction or donation of
impounded dogs shall be by humane means prescribed by the state of Illinois animal control act.
B. Cats: It is the duty of the police chief, or any person or entity designated by him, to destroy any cat unredeemed at the expiration of five (5)
days from the time of capture, or to provide for its donation to a licensed animal shelter facility and it shall be lawful for the village police to kill
any vicious cat at large within the limits of the village which cannot safely be taken up and impounded. Any such destruction or donation of
impounded cats shall be by humane means prescribed by the state of Illinois animal control act. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-5-15: KENNELS:
The possession of three (3) or more dogs by any person shall constitute prima facie evidence of the maintenance of a dog kennel for the sale of
dogs. All persons operating a dog kennel within the limits of the village shall pay an annual license fee as prescribed in this code. (Ord. 09-48, 10-
19-2009)
15-5-16: ADDITIONAL REGULATIONS FOR CATS:
A. Number Of Cats Restricted: It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a licensed kennel, pet shop or shelter operator, to keep or harbor
more than two (2) cats over the age of six (6) months. The keeping of more than two (2) cats over the age of six (6) months is declared to be a
public nuisance and is declared to be detrimental to the public health, safety and welfare.
B. Cat Bites: In the event that a cat bites a person, the chief of police, or any person designated by him, shall immediately notify the animal
control administrator, pursuant to the state of Illinois animal control act, and said cat shall be impounded as provided therein. (Ord. 09-48, 10-
19-2009)
Chapter 6
ASSAULT AND BATTERY, FIGHTING
15-6-1: UNLAWFUL:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit an assault or battery or to fight in any public place in the village. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)

Chapter 7
BARBED WIRE, ELECTRIC FENCES
15-7-1: UNLAWFUL:
It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain anywhere in the village a fence equipped with or having barbed wire spikes or any similar device, or any
electric charge sufficient to cause shock, within seven feet (7') of the ground level. This chapter shall not apply to invisible perimeter fences for the
retention of animals. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)

Chapter 9
DANGEROUS EXCAVATIONS
15-9-1: UNLAWFUL:
It shall be unlawful for the owner of any real property located within the village to maintain or permit the existence upon such property of any
excavation, pit, hole, ditch or other manmade depression in the earth, which endangers the public health, welfare and safety or the real or
personal property of another. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 10
DISORDERLY CONDUCT
15-10-1: UNLAWFUL ACTIVITIES:
A person commits disorderly conduct when that person knowingly:
A. Does any act in such unreasonable manner as to provoke, make or aid in making a breach of peace; or
B. Does or makes any unreasonable or offensive act, utterance, gesture or display which, under the circumstances, creates a clear and present
danger of a breach of peace or imminent threat of violence; or
C. Refuses or fails to cease and desist any peaceful conduct or activity likely to produce a breach of peace where there is an imminent threat of
violence, and where the police have made all reasonable efforts to protect the otherwise peaceful conduct and activity, and have requested
that said conduct and activity be stopped and explained the request if there be time; or
D. Fails to obey a lawful order of dispersal by a person known by him to be a police officer under circumstances which acts are likely to cause
substantial harm or serious inconvenience, annoyance or alarm; or assembles for the purpose of using force or violence to disturb the public
peace; or
E. Goes about begging or soliciting funds on the public ways, except as provided for by ordinance or upon lawful authority of the village; or
F. Carries in a threatening or menacing manner, without authority of law, any dagger, razor, dangerous knife, stiletto, knuckles, slingshot, billy,
stun gun or taser, crossbow, common or compound bows, underwater spear gun, blackjack, sand club, sandbag, throwing star, nunchaku,
broken bottle or other piece of glass, air gun, air pistol, spring gun, spring pistol, BB gun, paintball gun, pellet gun or any implement that is not
a firearm which impels a breakable paintball containing washable marking colors, or a pellet constructed of hard plastic, steel, lead or other
hard materials with a force that reasonably is expected to cause bodily harm, look alike weapon which by its appearance, including shape,
color, size, markings or lack thereof, or any other identifying physical characteristic, would lead a reasonable person to believe that the object
is a weapon which could cause bodily harm, an object containing noxious or deleterious liquid, gas or substance or other dangerous weapon;
or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 374/387
G. While on public or private grounds adjacent to any building in which a school or any class thereof is in session, wilfully makes or assists in the
making of any noise or diversion which disturbs or tends to disturb the peace or good order of such school session or class thereof.
H. The use of loudspeakers, amplifiers or organized chanting or shouting within three hundred feet (300') of any school or class thereof is
presumed to disturb the peace or good order of such school session or class thereof.
I. No person shall maliciously turn in or cause to be turned in a false alarm including, but not limited to, abuse of the 911 system, filing false police
reports, or other improper usage of the police or fire dispatch system. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 11
DISTURBING ASSEMBLAGES
15-11-1: UNLAWFUL:
It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any lawful assemblage or gathering in the village. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 12
FIREWORKS
15-12-1: PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful to sell, store, possess, discharge or set off any fireworks or to give any pyrotechnic display in the village, except in connection
with public exhibitions as is herein provided. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-12-2: SALE OF FIREWORKS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, possess, offer for sale or keep for the purpose of selling any fireworks in the village at any time. (Ord.
09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-12-3: PUBLIC DISPLAY:
No public exhibition of fireworks or pyrotechnics shall be given unless a permit therefor is first secured from the village. All such public displays
shall be under the supervision of a competent person, and shall be superintended by the fire chief or some other member of the fire department
assigned this duty by him. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 13
GAMBLING
15-13-1: PROHIBITED:
A. Generally: It shall be unlawful to gamble or to attend any gambling resort or to make any bet, lottery or gambling hazard or to buy or sell any
chances or tickets in any gambling game, arrangement or device, except as provided herein.
B. Sporting Events: It shall be unlawful for any person to place, make, accept, relay, deliver or pay any wager or bet on any sporting event or
other competition.
C. Exceptions:
1. Lottery: This chapter shall not apply to the lottery owned and operated by the state, bingo, casino nights, raffles or such similarly situated
events hosted by not for profit organizations and which are allowed by the state and which have received the necessary permitting from the
state and village.
2. Video Gaming: This chapter shall not apply to "video gaming" as defined by the Illinois gaming act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 40. (Ord.
13-71, 11-18-2013)
15-13-1-1: VIDEO GAMING:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 375/387
A. Authority To Regulate: This section is passed pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes sections 5/11-42-2 and 5/11-55-1, and 35 Illinois
Compiled Statutes section 510/1 et seq., 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 40/1 et seq.
B. Definitions:
VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL: Any electronic video game machine that, upon insertion of cash, electronic cards or vouchers or any
combination thereof, is available to play or simulate the play of a video game, including, but not limited to, video poker, line up, and blackjack,
as authorized by the village, utilizing a video display and microprocessors in which the player may receive free games or credits that can be
redeemed for cash. The term does not include a machine that directly dispenses coins, cash, or tokens or is for amusement purposes only.
The village adopts the definitions contained within 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 40/5, "Definitions", and any amendments thereto.
C. License Required: No person shall keep or display for operating or patronage by the public within the village any video gaming terminal without
first having obtained a written license therefor from the village, which license shall be framed and hung in plain view in a conspicuous place on
the licensed premises, and such posted license may include more than one device on such licensed premises. It shall be a prerequisite to any
license from the village that the person keeping the video gaming terminal have a valid license from the state of Illinois for each such device
and the loss or suspension of any such license by the state of Illinois shall automatically result in the same status for the license issued
hereunder, without refund of any license fee.
D. Fee: There hereby is imposed on the privilege of operating every video gaming terminal in the village, as defined by the Illinois video gaming
act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 40/1 et seq., an annual fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each such device.
E. Application Form Required: An application for an amusement device license shall be made to the village on forms furnished by the village. The
application shall set forth the number of video gaming terminals for which permission is sought for a particular premises, shall describe the
number and type of each different device or machine that the applicant intends to operate and shall be accompanied by payment of the
appropriate fee. The applicant shall include a copy of the license from the state of Illinois for each video gaming terminal at that location.
F. Penalty: Violations of this section shall be subject to the general penalty contained in title 1, chapter 4, "General Penalty", of this code. (Ord.
13-71, 11-18-2013)
15-13-2: GAMBLING DEVICES:
It shall be unlawful to possess any gambling device or paraphernalia with the intent to use the same for an unlawful purpose, and any such device
or paraphernalia kept with such intent may be confiscated by the chief of police or his designee. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-13-3: GAMBLING HOUSES:
It shall be unlawful to maintain or patronize any establishment maintained as a gambling house or resort, except as authorized by the Illinois
gaming act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 40 et seq., and this chapter. (Ord. 13-71, 11-18-2013)
15-13-4: ADVERTISING:
It shall be unlawful to advertise any gambling house or gambling resort on any street, in any alley of public place within the village, except as
authorized by the Illinois gaming act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 40 et seq., and this chapter. (Ord. 13-71, 11-18-2013)
Chapter 14
INDECENT ACTIVITIES; FIGHTING
15-14-1: UNLAWFUL ACTIVITIES:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person to:
1. Profanity: Use profanity on any street, alley or other public place in the village.
2. Indecent Publications: Keep any profane, obscene or adult publication, printed or written matter, picture, product, or other representation in
any place frequented by or where it may come into the possession of minors or to disclose or expose any such material to a minor.
3. Fighting: Knowingly start fights, fight or commit any assault or battery in any public place in the village.
4. Adult Stores; Minors: Permit any person under the age of eighteen (18) years old to be on the premises of any "adult store" or any other
location that houses an adult use, as defined in this code.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 376/387
5. Urination And Defecation In Public: Urinate or defecate in or on a public street, alley, sidewalk, yard, park, building, structure, plaza, public
or utility right of way, or other public place, other than in a restroom or in public view. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 15
INTERFERING WITH VILLAGE OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
15-15-1: UNLAWFUL:
It shall be unlawful to interfere with or hinder any officer or employee of the village while engaged in the duties of his office. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-
2009)
Chapter 16
LITTERING; VILLAGE PARKING LOTS
15-16-1: PROHIBITED:
No person shall litter or otherwise cause the placement of garbage or trash in a public place, including village owned parking lots, except in
receptacles designated for same. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-16-2: VILLAGE PARKING LOTS:
No person shall use village owned parking lots, except for parking purposes, unless otherwise permitted; no person shall use village owned
parking lots to repair or maintain a vehicle parked therein. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 17
LOITERING
15-17-1: DEFINITIONS:
Definitions under this section shall be as follows:
LOITERING: Remaining idle in essentially one location and includes the concept of spending time idly; to be dilatory; to linger; to sleep in a public
place; to stand around and shall also include the colloquial expression "hanging around".
PUBLIC PLACE: Any place to which the general public has access and a right to resort for business, entertainment, or other lawful purpose, but
does not necessarily mean a place devoted solely to the uses of the public. It shall also include the front or immediate area of any store, shop,
restaurant, tavern or other place of business and also public grounds, areas, parks or schools. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-17-2: PROHIBITED ACTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter, loaf, wander, stand or remain idle either alone and/or in consort with others in a public place in such
manner so as to:
A. Obstruct any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building by hindering or impeding or tending to hinder or
impede the free and uninterrupted passage of vehicles, traffic or pedestrians.
B. Commit in or upon any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building any act or thing which is an
obstruction or interference to the free and uninterrupted use of property or with any business lawfully conducted by anyone in or upon or
facing or fronting on any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building, all of which prevents the free and
uninterrupted ingress, egress and regress, therein, thereon and thereto. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-17-3: VIOLATIONS:
When any person causes or commits any of the conditions or acts enumerated in this chapter, a police officer or any law enforcement officer shall
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 377/387
order that person to stop causing or committing such conditions or acts and to move on or disperse. Any person who fails or refuses to obey such
orders shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 18
MINORS
15-18-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following definitions apply:
CURFEW HOURS: A. Eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday until six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of the
following day;
B. One minute after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. to six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on Saturday; and
C. One minute after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. to six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on Sunday.
EMERGENCY: An unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action. The term includes, but is not
limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, an automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of
life.
ESTABLISHMENT: Any privately owned place of business operated for a profit to which the public is invited, including, but not limited to, any
place of amusement or entertainment.
GUARDIAN: A. A person who, under court order, is the guardian of the person of a minor; or
B. A public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by the court.
MINOR FOR PURPOSES OF CURFEW: Any person under seventeen (17) years of age.
OPERATOR: Any individual, firm, association, partnership, or corporation operating, managing, or conducting any establishment. The term
includes the members or partners of an association or partnership and the officers of a corporation.
PARENT: A person who is:
A. A natural parent, adoptive parent, or stepparent of another person; or
B. At least seventeen (17) years of age and authorized by a parent or guardian to have the care and custody of a minor.
PUBLIC PLACE: Any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access and includes, but is not limited to, streets,
highways, and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transport facilities, and shops.
SERIOUS BODILY INJURY: Bodily injury that creates a substantial risk of death or that causes death, serious permanent disfigurement, or
protracted loss or impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-18-2: CURFEW OFFENSES:
A. A minor commits an offense if he remains in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the village during curfew hours.
B. A parent or guardian of a minor commits an offense if he knowingly permits, or by insufficient control allows, the minor to remain in any public
place or on the premises of any establishment within the village during curfew hours.
C. The owner, operator, or any employee of an establishment commits an offense if he knowingly allows a minor to remain upon the premises of
the establishment during curfew hours. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-18-3: CURFEW DEFENSES:
It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the minor was:
A. Accompanied by the minor's parent or guardian;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 378/387
B. On an errand at the direction of the minor's parent or guardian, without any detour or stop;
C. In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel;
D. Engaged in an employment activity, or going to or returning home from an employment activity, without any detour or stop;
E. Involved in an emergency;
F. On the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence or abutting the residence of a next door neighbor if the neighbor did not complain to the police
department about the minor's presence;
G. Attending an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults or sponsored by the village, a civic organization, or
another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor, or going to or returning home from, without any detour or stop;
H. Exercising first amendment rights protected by the United States constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the
right of assembly; or
I. Married or had been married or is an emancipated minor under the emancipation of mature minor act, as amended.
J. It is a defense to prosecution that the owner, operator, or employee of an establishment promptly notified the police department that a minor
was present on the premises of the establishment during curfew hours and refused to leave. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-18-4: POLICE DETENTION:
Each member of the police force is hereby authorized to take custody of without warrant, any person violating any provisions of this chapter and
retain such person until he or she is turned over to the custody of the parent, guardian or other person having the legal care and custody of such
child. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-18-5: ENFORCEMENT:
Before taking any enforcement action under this section, a police officer shall ask the apparent offender's age and reason for being in the public
place. The officer shall not issue a citation or take custody of the minor under this section unless the officer reasonably believes that an offense
has occurred and that, based on any response and other circumstances, no defense in this chapter is present. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-18-6: TOBACCO:
See chapter 26 of this title. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-18-7: TRUANCY:
See chapter 28 of this title. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-18-8: VANDALISM:
See chapter 29 of this title. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 19
OBSCENE PUBLICATIONS AND PRODUCTIONS
15-19-1: SALES AND DISTRIBUTION:
A. It is unlawful for any person to knowingly sell, give, deliver, present, publish or exhibit obscene material, or obscene productions of any sort,
including, but not limited to, writings, pictures, movies, performances, acts, plays or dances, to any person.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 379/387
B. For the purpose of this section, a material or a production shall be considered obscene if, applying contemporary community standards for the
average person to whom it is sold, given, delivered, presented, published or exhibited:
1. It, as a whole, appeals to the prurient interest; and
2. It contains either patently offensive representations or descriptions of ultimate sexual acts, normal or perverted, actual or simulated, or
patently offensive representations or descriptions of masturbation, erectory functions and lewd exhibition of the genitals; and
3. It, taken as a whole, lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value or otherwise is not found to be obscene. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-
2009)
15-19-2: SALES PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, or exhibit for sale, in sealed form or in any form which indicates that the sale thereof is surreptitious or
contrary to law, any book, pamphlet or literature of any kind bearing the title of some well known book of salacious character or bearing the title of
a book of which the contents are actually lewd, lascivious, obscene, immoral, or indecent. It shall likewise be unlawful to sell or exhibit for sale,
any book, pamphlet or literature of any kind having anything about it which indicates that its contents are of an obscene, immoral, lewd, lascivious
or indecent character; or to sell, offer or exhibit for sale, any of said materials under the guise or pretense that the same is obscene, immoral,
lewd, lascivious or indecent; or in a manner that indicates concealment of anything as contrary to law or immoral contained therein; or to use any
pretense, trick, fraud, artifice or device to convey the impression that such materials are lewd, lascivious, indecent, obscene or immoral, whether
such pretense, trick, fraud, artifice or device is a misrepresentation in regard to the contents of the same or not. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-19-3: SALE TO MINORS:
It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to exhibit, sell, offer to sell, give away, circulate or distribute or attempt to distribute to any person
under the age of eighteen (18) years, any obscene book, pornographic material, magazine, pamphlet, paper, writing, card, advertisement,
circular, print, picture, photograph, motion picture film, play, image, instrument, statue, drawing or other material.
"Obscene" for the purpose of this section is defined as follows: Whether to the average person under eighteen (18) years of age to whom the
material is exhibited, sold, offered for sale, given away, circulated or distributed, applying contemporary community standards, the dominant
theme of the material taken as a whole appeals to prurient interests.
In determining whether the publication or other material is obscene and whether the dominant theme of the material taken as a whole appeals to
prurient interests, consideration shall be given to whatever artistic, literary, historical or educational value the publication or other material may
have for persons under the age of eighteen (18) years in the community and whether the probability of the appeal to prurient interests is so great
as to outweigh whatever artistic, literary, historical, educational or other merit the publication or other material may possess. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-
2009)
Chapter 20
CANNABIS AND CANNABIS PARAPHERNALIA
15-20-1: DEFINITIONS:
CANNABIS: Includes marijuana, hashish and other substances which are identified as including any part of the plant Cannabis sativa, whether
growing or not; the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any part of such plant; and any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or
preparation of such plant, its seeds or resin, including tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and all other cannabinol derivatives, including its naturally
occurring or synthetically produced ingredients, whether produced directly or indirectly by extraction, or independently by means of chemical
synthesis or by a combination of extraction and chemical synthesis; but shall not include the mature stalks of such plant, fiber produced from such
stalks, oil or cake made from the seeds of such plant, any other compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of such mature
stalks (except the resin extracted therefrom), fiber, oil or cake or the sterilized seed of such plant which is incapable of germination.
CANNABIS PARAPHERNALIA: Includes all equipment, products and materials of any kind which are peculiar to, or marketed for use, or are
used, in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing,
testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing into the human
body cannabis in violation of the cannabis control act. It includes, but is not limited to:
A. Kits peculiar to and marketed for use, or used in manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing or preparing cannabis;
B. Isomerization devices peculiar to, or marketed for use, or used in increasing the potency of any species of plant which is cannabis;
C. Testing equipment peculiar to, or marketed for private home use in, or used for, identifying or analyzing the strength, effectiveness or purity
of cannabis;
D. Diluents and adulterants peculiar to, or marketed for use in, or used for, cutting cannabis or a controlled substance by private persons;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 380/387
E. Objects peculiar to, marketed for use in, or used for ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing cannabis, cocaine, hashish, or hashish oil
into the human body including, where applicable, the following terms:
1. Water pipes;
2. Carburetion tubes and devices;
3. Smoking and carburetion masks;
4. Carburetor pipes;
5. Electric pipes;
6. Air driven pipes;
7. Chillums;
8. Bongs;
9. Ice pipes or chillers;
F. Any item whose purpose, as announced or described by the seller, is for use in violation of this section. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-20-2: UNLAWFUL:
It is unlawful for any person knowingly to possess any quantity of any substance containing cannabis and/or paraphernalia as described herein
for the use thereof, except that the effect of this section shall be limited to persons knowingly possessing less than thirty grams (30 g) of any
substance containing cannabis. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-20-3: POSSESSION OF PARAPHERNALIA:
A. A person who knowingly possesses an item of drug paraphernalia with the intent to use it in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing
cannabis into the human body, or in preparing cannabis substance for that use, is guilty of the offense hereunder.
B. In determining intent, the proximity of the cannabis drug paraphernalia or the presence of cannabis on the drug paraphernalia may be
considered. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-20-4: EXEMPT ITEMS; DETERMINATION:
A. Items marketed for the use in the preparation, compounding, packaging, labeling, or other use of cannabis as an incident to lawful research,
teaching, or chemical analysis and not for sale; or
B. Items marketed for, or historically and customarily used in connection with the planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting,
manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing,
concealing, injecting, ingesting, or inhaling of tobacco or any other lawful substance.
C. Items exempt under this section include, but are not limited to, garden hoes, rakes, sickles, baggies, tobacco pipes, and cigarette rolling
papers.
D. Items which are marketed for decorative purposes, when such items have been rendered completely inoperable or incapable of being used for
any illicit purpose prohibited by this section. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-20-5: CONSIDERATIONS:
In determining whether or not a particular item is exempt under this chapter, all other logically relevant factors should be considered, including the
following:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 381/387
A. The general, usual, customary, and historical use to which the item involved has been put;
B. Expert evidence concerning the ordinary or customary use of the item and the effect of any peculiarity in the design or engineering of the item
upon its functioning;
C. Any written instructions accompanying the delivery of the item concerning the purposes or uses to which the item can or may be put;
D. Any oral instructions provided by the seller of the item at the time and place of sale or commercial delivery;
E. Any national or local advertising, concerning the design, purpose or use of the item involved, and the entire context in which such advertising
occurs;
F. The manner, place and circumstances in which the item was displayed for sale, as well as any item or items displayed for sale or otherwise
exhibited upon the premises where the sale was made;
G. Whether the owner or anyone in control of the object is a legitimate supplier of like or related items to the community, such as a licensed
distributor or dealer of tobacco products;
H. The existence and scope of legitimate uses for the object in the community. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 21
PROSTITUTION
15-21-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter:
PROSTITUTION, PANDERING AND SOLICITING FOR A PROSTITUTE: Have the same meanings given them in the Illinois criminal code, as
amended.
PUBLIC PLACE: Any street, sidewalk, bridge, alley or alleyway, plaza, park, driveway, parking lot or transportation facility or the doorways and
entranceways to any building which fronts on any of the aforesaid places, or a motor vehicle in or on any such place, or any other public way.
(Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-21-2: SOLICITATION:
A. Any person who remains or wanders about in a public place and beckons to, or repeatedly attempts to engage passersby in conversation, or
repeatedly interferes with the free passage of other persons, for the purpose of prostitution or of soliciting for a prostitute, shall be guilty of a
violation of this chapter.
B. Any person who remains or wanders about in a public place and beckons to, or repeatedly stops, or repeatedly attempts to stop, or repeatedly
attempts to engage passersby in conversation, or repeatedly stops or attempts to stop motor vehicles, or repeatedly interferes with the free
passage of other persons, for the purpose of pandering shall be guilty of a violation of this section. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-21-3: VIOLATION:
A. Any person who appears in a public place and exposes the genitals, vulva, pubis, pubic hair, buttocks, perineum, anus, anal region or pubic
hair region, or any portion of the female breast at or below the upper edge of the areola, for the purpose of prostitution shall be guilty of a
violation of this chapter.
B. Any person who responds to the beckoning of a prostitute in a public place by inquiring about, negotiating for, accepting an offer of or engaging
in an act of prostitution, or by allowing another into his or her motor vehicle for purposes of inquiring about, negotiating for, accepting an offer
of or engaging in an act of prostitution, shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter. The chief of police shall make available to local
newspapers, radio and television stations the names of all persons charged with violating this chapter. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-21-4: VEHICLE IMPOUNDMENT:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 382/387
A. A motor vehicle that is used in the violation of this chapter or in the commission of prostitution, soliciting for a prostitute, soliciting for a juvenile
prostitute as, or patronizing a juvenile prostitute, shall be subject to seizure and impoundment as provided in title 7, chapter 4.2 of this code.
B. Whenever a police officer has probable cause to believe that a vehicle is subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant to this section, the
police officer shall provide for the towing of the vehicle to a facility controlled by the city or its agents. When the vehicle is towed, the police
officer shall notify the person who is found to be in control of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation, if there is such a person, of the fact
of the seizure and of the vehicle owner's right to request a preliminary hearing. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 22
PUBLIC NUDITY
15-22-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this chapter, "nudity" means the display of the human male or female genitalia; pubic hair; buttocks; perineum; anal or pubic regions;
female breast, at or below the areola thereof, with no covering or with a less than fully opaque covering; or, male genitalia, in a discernible turgid
state, with or without covering. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-22-2: PROHIBITED:
No person shall knowingly or intentionally, in a public place other than a nonretail adult business, appear in a state of nudity in the village. This
section shall not apply to public nudity necessarily incidental to breastfeeding a child. "Public place" shall, for the purposes of this chapter, mean
any place, or a part of a place, to which the public, or a section of the public, ordinarily has access, whether or not by payment or by invitation
(including, for example, a shop, restaurant, hotel, cinema or club). (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 23
REFUSE DEPOSITS
15-23-1: UNLAWFUL ACTIVITIES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to:
A. Windblown Refuse: Deposit or leave any refuse or material in such a place or condition that it can be blown by the wind so as to be scattered
or cause clouds of dust or particles; and it shall be unlawful to permit the escape of soot, ashes or other solid products or results of
combustion so as to be windblown or scattered.
B. Deposits On Streets: Dump or deposit, or cause to be dumped or deposited any grass, leaves, branches, garbage, refuse, hazardous or
harmful materials, or any other things in the roadway or gutter of any public street in the village. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 24
RESISTING ARREST
15-24-1: UNLAWFUL:
Whoever in the village shall resist any member of the police force or any other person duly authorized to perform police duty in the discharge of
his duties, or shall in any way interfere with, prevent or hinder him in the discharge of his duty as such member, or shall offer or endeavor to do so
shall be punished as provided in chapter 1 of this title. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 25
RETAIL THEFT
15-25-1: PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit an act of retail theft within the village limits. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-25-2: DEFINITIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 383/387
For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
FULL RETAIL VALUE: The merchant's stated or advertised price of the merchandise.
LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian, or given custody, of a minor by a circuit court of the state, but does not include a person
appointed guardian, or given custody, of a minor under the juvenile court act of 1987, 705 Illinois Compiled Statutes 405/1 et seq.
MERCHANDISE: Any item of tangible personal property.
MERCHANT: An owner or operator of any retail mercantile establishment or any agent, employee, lessee, consignee, officer, director, franchisee
or independent contractor of such owner or operator.
MINOR: A person who is above eleven (11) years but not yet eighteen (18) years of age.
PARENT: The lawful father and mother of a minor child, whether by birth or adoption.
PERSON: Any natural person or individual.
POLICE OFFICER: Has the meaning and encompasses the powers and duties ascribed to that term in this code and Illinois law.
PREMISES OF A RETAIL MERCANTILE ESTABLISHMENT: Includes, but is not limited to, the retail mercantile establishment; any common use
areas in shopping centers and all parking areas set aside by a merchant or on behalf of a merchant for the parking of vehicles for the
convenience of the patrons of such retail mercantile establishment.
RETAIL MERCANTILE ESTABLISHMENT: Any place where merchandise is displayed, held, stored or offered for sale to the public.
SHOPPING CART: Those pushcarts of the type or types which are commonly provided by grocery stores, drugstores or other retail mercantile
establishments for the use of the public in transporting commodities in stores and markets and, incidentally, from the stores to a place outside the
store.
THEFT DETECTION REMOVAL DEVICE: Any tool or device specifically designed and intended to be used to remove any theft detection device
from any merchandise.
THEFT DETECTION SHIELDING DEVICE: Any laminated or coated bag or device designed and intended to shield merchandise from detection
by an electronic or magnetic theft alarm sensor.
TO CONCEAL MERCHANDISE: Although there may be some notice of its presence, that merchandise is not visible through ordinary
observation.
UNDER RING: To cause the cash register or other sales recording device to reflect less than the full retail value of the merchandise. (Ord. 09-48,
10-19-2009)
15-25-3: VIOLATION:
A person commits the offense of retail theft when he or she knowingly:
A. Takes possession of, carries away, transfers or causes to be carried away or transferred any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for
sale in a retail mercantile establishment with the intention of retaining such merchandise or with the intention of depriving the merchant
permanently of the possession, use or benefit of such merchandise without paying the full retail value of such merchandise; or
B. Alters, transfers, or removes any label, price tag, marking, indicia of value or any other markings which aid in determining value affixed to any
merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale, in a retail mercantile establishment and attempts to purchase such merchandise
personally or in consort with another at less than the full retail value with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such
merchandise; or
C. Transfers any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale, in a retail mercantile establishment from the container in or on which
such merchandise is displayed to any other container with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise;
or
D. Under rings with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of the merchandise; or
E. Removes a shopping cart from the premises of a retail mercantile establishment without the consent of the merchant given at the time of such
removal with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of such cart; or
F. Represents to a merchant that he or another is the lawful owner of property, knowing that such representation is false, and conveys or attempts
to convey that property to a merchant who is the owner of the property in exchange for money, merchandise credit or other property of the
merchant; or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 384/387
G. Uses or possesses any theft detection shielding device or theft detection device remover with the intention of using such device to deprive the
merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail mercantile
establishment without paying the full retail value of such merchandise; or
H. Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner and thereby intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit
of the property when a lessee of the personal property of another fails to return it to the owner, or if the lessee fails to pay the full retail value of
such property to the lessor in satisfaction of any contractual provision requiring such, within ten (10) days after written demand from the owner
for its return. A notice in writing, given after the expiration of the leasing agreement, by registered mail, to the lessee at the address given by
the lessee and shown on the leasing agreement shall constitute proper demand. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-25-4: RIGHT TO DETAIN:
Any merchant who has reasonable grounds to believe that a person has committed retail theft may detain such person, on or off the premises of
a retail mercantile establishment, for all or any of the following purposes:
A. To request and to verify any and all identification;
B. To make reasonable inquiry as to whether such person has in his possession unpurchased merchandise and, to make reasonable investigation
as to the ownership of the merchandise;
C. To inform a peace officer of the detention of the person and surrender that person to the custody of a peace officer; and/or
D. In the case of a minor, to immediately make a reasonable attempt to inform the parents, guardian or other private person interested in the
welfare of that minor and, at the merchant's discretion, a police officer, of the minor's detention and to surrender custody of such minor to
either the minor's parents, guardian, private interested person or police officer. A merchant may make a detention as permitted herein off the
premises of a retail mercantile establishment only if such detention is pursuant to an immediate pursuit of such person. Merchant shall be
deemed to have reasonable grounds to make a detention for the purposes of this section if the merchant detains a person because such
person has in his possession either a theft detection shielding device or a theft detection device remover.
E. In the case of a minor person who is accused of violating any of the provisions of this section and who is residing with a parent or guardian at
the time of such purported violation, the juvenile department of the village police department shall, within three (3) days thereof, notify such
parent or guardian, in writing, either by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, that such minor has been accused of retail theft.
(Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-25-5: DOLLAR LIMIT ENFORCEMENT:
The code hearing department of the village as defined in title 1, chapter 13 of this code shall only enforce the provisions of this chapter if the retail
value of the item subject to retail theft is less than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 26
TOBACCO
15-26-1: MINORS:
No minor under eighteen (18) years of age shall buy any cigar, cigarette, smokeless tobacco or tobacco in any of its forms. No person shall sell,
purchase for, distribute samples of or furnish any cigar, cigarette, smokeless tobacco or tobacco in any of its forms, to any minor under eighteen
(18) years of age. For the purpose of this chapter, "smokeless tobacco" means any tobacco products that are suitable for dipping or chewing.
(Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-26-2: VENDING MACHINES:
A. Tobacco products listed above may be sold through a vending machine only in the following locations:
1. Factories, businesses, offices, private clubs, and other places not open to the general public.
2. Places to which minors under eighteen (18) years of age are not permitted access.
3. Places where alcoholic beverages are sold and consumed on the premises.
4. Places where the vending machine is under the direct supervision of the owner of the establishment or an employee over eighteen (18)
years of age. The sale of tobacco products from a vending machine under direct supervision of the owner or an employee of the
establishment is considered a sale of tobacco products by that person. As used in this subsection, "direct supervision" means that the
owner or employee has an unimpeded line of sight to the vending machine. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 385/387
15-26-3: LUNCH WAGONS:
The sale or distribution of cigarettes from a lunch wagon engaging in any sales activity within one thousand feet (1,000') of any public or private
elementary or secondary school grounds is prohibited. For the purpose of this section, "lunch wagon" means a mobile vehicle designed and
constructed to transport food and from which food is sold to the general public. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-26-4: SALE AND DISTRIBUTION OF CIGARETTES:
It shall be unlawful to sell individual cigarettes or cigars (if packed in multiple sealed units) in any quantities less than a full sealed pack. (Ord. 09-
48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 27
TRESPASSES
15-27-1: UNLAWFUL:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit a trespass within this municipality upon either public or private property. Without constituting any
limitation upon the provisions of this section, any of the following acts by any person shall be deemed included among those that constitute
trespasses in violation of the provisions hereof and appropriate action may be taken hereunder at any time, or from time to time, to prevent or
suppress any violation or violations of this section, the aforesaid enumerated acts so included, being as follows:
A. Any entry upon the premises or any part thereof, of another, including any public property in violation of a notice posted or exhibited at the
main entrance to such premises or at any point of approach or entry or in violation of any notice, warning or protest given orally or in writing,
by any owner or occupant thereof; or
B. An entry into or upon any vehicle or watercraft made without the consent of the person having the right to the possession or control thereof, or
a failure or refusal to leave any such vehicle or watercraft after being requested to leave by the person having such right; or
C. A failure or refusal to depart from the premises of another in case of being requested either orally or in writing, to leave by any owner or
occupant thereof; or
D. The pursuit of a course of conduct or action incidental to the making of an entry upon the land of another in violation of a notice posted or
exhibited at the main entrance to such premises or any point of approach or entry, or in violation of any notice, warning or protest given orally
or in writing by any owner or occupant thereof. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 28
TRUANCY
15-28-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian, or given custody, of a minor by a circuit court of the state, but does not include a person
appointed guardian or given custody of a minor under the juvenile court act of 1987, 705 Illinois Compiled Statutes 405/1 et seq.
MINOR: Any person over five (5) but who shall not have reached eighteen (18) years of age.
PARENT: The lawful father or mother of a minor child whether by birth or adoption.
UNEMANCIPATED MINOR: A minor still under the care and custody of his parents. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-28-2: ABSENCE:
It shall be unlawful for any minor enrolled in a public, private or parochial school within the corporate limits of the village to absent himself from
attendance at such school without prior written permission of his parent or legal guardian having been filed with the proper school authorities.
Emergencies or unforeseen absences due to illness or other causes beyond the control of the absentee minor shall not constitute truancy if
permission for such absence has, in substance, been obtained from the parent or legal guardian, and such permission is confirmed in writing and
filed with the proper school authorities within twenty four (24) hours after such absence. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-28-3: PRESENCE ON PUBLIC WAY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 386/387
It shall be unlawful for any juvenile, between the age of seven (7) and sixteen (16) years who is subject to compulsory school attendance
pursuant to the Illinois school code, whether attending a public, private or parochial school, who has been expelled or suspended from attending
such school, and who is not otherwise subject to the truancy laws established by the Illinois school code, to be upon any public road, street, alley,
park or other lands used for public purposes or in any public place of business or amusement within the village during the daytime hours when
such schools are in session. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-28-4: PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY:
It shall be unlawful for a parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor residing with said parent or legal guardian to knowingly allow or
knowingly permit said minor child to violate or attempt to violate any portion of this chapter. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-28-5: COMMUNITY SERVICE:
In addition to or in lieu of the penalties applicable to this chapter a period of community service not to exceed one hundred sixty (160) hours may
be imposed upon a minor who violates any provision of this chapter. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 29
VANDALISM
15-29-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires, the terms specified have the following meanings ascribed to them:
ACTS OF VANDALISM: Include any of the following:
Recklessly or knowingly damaging or destroying any property of another person without his or her consent; or
Recklessly or knowingly by means of fire or explosive device, damaging, debasing or destroying any property of another person without his
or her consent; or
Recklessly or knowingly starting a fire on land of another person without his or her consent; or
Recklessly or knowingly depositing on the land or in the building of another person, without his consent, any stink bomb, any offensive
smelling compound or any other offensive or dangerous compound or item and thereby interfering with the use and occupancy by another,
of the land or building; or
Recklessly or knowingly and without authority entering into or obtaining control over any building, house trailer, motor vehicle, aircraft or
watercraft, or any part thereof, of another person without his or her consent.
LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor by a circuit court of the state, but does not include a person
appointed guardian or given custody of a minor under the juvenile court act.
MINOR: A person who is above the age of eleven (11) years, but not yet eighteen (18) years of age.
PERSON: Includes any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind.
PROPERTY: Includes any real estate including improvements thereon, and tangible personalty.
RESTITUTION: Includes paying to a person who owns property damaged or destroyed by an act of vandalism in an amount equal to the
damages incurred as a result of the act of vandalism and shall also include undertaking at the direction of the police department juvenile officer
tasks designed to correct damage resulting from acts of vandalism or other work which will provide a benefit to the village and its citizens. (Ord.
09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-29-2: PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully, maliciously or negligently break, deface, injure or destroy any property within the village, whether
such property is owned by the state, county, village or any other governmental body or owned by any private person. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-29-3: PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY:
Upon the occurrences of the events described as follows, the parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor residing with such parent or
legal guardian shall be presumed, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to have failed to exercise proper parental responsibility, and said
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=811 387/387
minor shall be deemed to have committed the acts described below with the knowledge and permission of the parent or guardian, in violation of
this chapter:
A. An unemancipated minor residing with said parent or legal guardian shall either be adjudicated to be in violation of any ordinance, law or
statute by exhibiting wilful and malicious acts causing injury to a person or property or shall have incurred nonjudicial sanctions from another
official agency resulting from an admission of guilt of violation of any ordinance, law or statute prohibiting wilful and malicious acts causing
injury to a person or property; and
B. If any time within one year following receipt of the notice set forth above, said minor is either adjudicated to be in violation of any ordinance,
law or statute as described in subsection A of this section, or shall have incurred nonjudicial sanctions from another official agency resulting
from an admission of guilt of violation of any ordinance, law or statute as described in subsection A of this section. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
Chapter 30
WEAPONS
15-30-1: DANGEROUS WEAPONS:
The sale and use of bows and arrows, BB guns, slingshots and other dangerous weapons is prohibited except as otherwise provided. (Ord. 09-
48, 10-19-2009)
15-30-2: CONCEALED WEAPONS:
It shall be unlawful to carry any concealed weapons in the village without first having a license to carry such concealed weapon duly issued under
the laws of the state of Illinois. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-30-3: DISCHARGE OF FIREARMS:
It shall be unlawful to discharge any firearms or air gun in the village; provided that this section shall not be construed to prohibit any officer of the
law to discharge a firearm in the performance of his duty, nor any citizen to discharge a firearm when lawfully defending his person or property.
(Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
15-30-4: HUNTING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to hunt or to engage in killing any animal other than as prescribed by law in the village. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-
2009)
Chapter 31
WHISTLES AND TRAINS
15-31-1: UNLAWFUL:
It shall be unlawful to blow or cause to be sounded any whistle or siren of any stationary engine or steam engine in the village except as a signal
for starting or stopping work, or in emergencies to avoid or prevent injury to persons or theft of property. (Ord. 09-48, 10-19-2009)
